text: Very inventive side dishes! Persimmon kimchi is out of this world! The owner makes it herself. Awesome
This place is super tasty. And it's actually open til 2 Am. I loved the dumpling soup I got and I love all the pickled sides that come with.

Authentic and delicious. The food was phenomenal and the service was attentive and quick. My boyfriend had his old stand by, bul go gi, and I had bi him bop (mostly so he could try it so I can broaden his Korean food horizons).. and they were both great. The ban chan (side dishes) were varied and had some authentic items that you don't regularly see in other Korean restaurants in the Valley. What I'm really excited about and can't wait to go back and try is the other menu items such as cha jjang myun (delicious noodles in black bean sauce) and cham pong (spicy seafood noodles)... These are also items rarely seen on a menu outside of k town.

Your place is amazing. Really good food, when I lived in the area I went there twice. Amazing both times. I just love how authentic your food taste. Idk what else to write to you but it's amazing. Great job!

Food was above average good. The service was very friendly and kind. But this tax issue other post mention is true and really weird. I asked the manager about the inflated tax and she seems suspiciously koi about it.  To compensate for the extra tax they charge, I lesson my tip. We drove 30 mins here and not quite sure I'd make that drive again for somewhat average food.

Check your bill!! My boyfriend and I only ordered one dish and we put both our cards in the receipt tray. She charged both of us full price for the dish we split!! We were out with friends, so we didn't catch it until we got home. Wish I would've caught it in time...I would have said something!! It's just wrong!!

This is Korean food with Korean Chinese dishes as well and it's my favorite place to go! If I could go more often I would but it's a bit of a drive for me. This is a small restaurant and is a bit dark, but the service is fantastic, the food is even better, and the prices are exactly where they should be. I've been all over, looking for a place like this and it fits all my expectations! This place is a gem and it's got great hours too! I highly recommend this place and so far, all my friends, coworkers, and family enjoy coming here, even though it's out of the way for most of them. If you're feeling spontaneous with trying new dishes or need a familiar taste of, gourmet, street fair plates or feel good foods from Korea, you should come here!

The most terrible service I have ever had, the actress's attitude is awful, order so slowly, if you separate you bill, she gives long face to customer, and this time I find a bug's wing in soup. I would never come here again.

My second visit to Cafe Ga Hyang confirmed everything about the first visit: 100% authentic Korean cuisine! It's as if I was back on Korea going for lunch on a lazy day off. If you're looking for the real deal on Korean food, then put Cafe Ga Hyang at the top of your list!

Yes.
I tried their dduk man doo guk (dumpling and rice cake soup in anchovy broth) -- AWESOME.

Soon doo boo is pretty good too.
Spicy tofu soup.

Their dduk bokki (spicy rice cakes) are SPICY and yummy.

Yook Gae Jang -- spicy broth, beef, clear noodles, veggies.
Spicy and yummy!

Jja Jang (soy bean paste noodle) and Neng Myun (spicy buckwheat noodle),
first few bites were good but then I got kinda tired of it.

Their sidedishes are well flavored.

Would recommend.

I want the original chef who went to LA to come back and make the awesome foods.

Never mind guys, the new chef's dishes were awesome too !

I have been coming to Cafe Ga Hyang for a few years now for Sunday lunch. 

The lady running the place is always very nice, I've never had any problems with service and have not seen anyone else have anything different. 

The food has always been well-made, even when I've ventured into unfamiliar territory and ordered entrees that don't fit my personal taste.

The food may take a bit longer to arrive at times, but it has never been an unreasonable amount of time for a restaurant. 

Favorite dishes: neng myun (cold noodles), jajang myun (black bean noodles), kalbi dolsot bibimbap (vegetable rice-bowl with beef served in stone bowl).

All of the side dishes are tasty, I haven't had a bad one yet. The gajajorim (glazed potatoes) and the spicy cucumber dish are my favorites.

My all time top favorite Korean places to go to. Great side dishes and Sue is such a sweetheart. I always order the Jap Chae (sp?) and it is really great! try it if you haven't had it yet. You wont be disappointed. Also Open very late which is always great

Horrible, just horrible! Went there last night for Korean food and the lady server was so mean to us we had to walk out of there while waiting for our food.

First of all, when I asked her about the menu and what her recommendation was, she was like "What do you want me to say? Just order what you like." 

OK, shook my head and ordered. Then we asked for ban-chan and she said she is not going to give it to us until we get our meal and that we had no common sense. She tried to give us a full lecture about how traditional way of eating Korean food should be. I did not go to this restaurant to get a lecture from this lady. I am Korean and I know how to eat Korean food! 

I have never received this kind of customer service in my life and I really think this lady needs to learn the basics of customer service. I'm from New York and I thought at least the people would be nicer than this. This is truly a shame that she treats people of her own kind like she did. 

People, be aware of this restaurant and go to Ohya restaurant which we went to after we escaped this hell hole. The customer service was amazing at Ohya! I don't know if the food might have been better at Cafe Gahyang but I certainly do not want to eat at a restaurant that has a kind of service she provided. Good thing I don't live around this area so I don't have to think about going back there LOL

I have eaten here approximately four times and was initially drawn to their amazing haemul pajeon (seafood pancakes).  The food is actually decent.  However, I have to take issue with the uneven service i've experienced there.  The last two times i've been there with my fiancé, the service was questionable.  

The first time, the owner seemed to want to get us out of there after we spent a couple hours of dinner and conversation.  She brought us to-go boxes early on and after a while, she came by and quickly boxed our food for us and then slammed the dishes together and walked away without saying a word.  We got the hint but totally rude and unnecessary especially considering the fact that it was not too busy.  

The second time, we ordered two dishes each and noticed that we were given only two side dishes.  Typically there are at least 4, sometimes 5 served with each customers dinner.  I figured they did not have much that night.  As we watched more customers come in and order, i noticed they were getting 5 side dishes.  Bewildered again.  

This was the last time we will visit this café.  I have no beef with the food - i thought it was very good.  I wanted to get it out there that restaurants will lose customers if the service is inconsistent and customers are not treated well...or even fairly for that matter.

We were looking for a place to eat and came across this place.  Great food with great people.  We didn't know what to get and they told us what was best and even showed us the best way to eat it.  The food is amazing and healthy!! This is our new spot and the best part is they're open late!!

Fantastic!  We were greeted so warmly and treated so well that it set the tone for the evening.  Restaurant a bit difficult to find as it's in a small plaza.  The bibimbap was absolutely outstanding.  Also impressive is the full array of mini tasters that come before the meal. So much fun.  Would highly recommend this.

I love this place. The women who run this place are very nice and will custom make anything for you. Food is really good but if you say spicy, be carefull because its gonna really be spicy. Best tai food i have had.

It was my first time trying out a new place for some late night eats, I had just got off work and was craving some Korean food and remembered hearing this place opens late and one thing led to another and boom I was there. I also took along my little brother for his first experience and he fell in love with it. Our waiter which was the owner I believe served us we weren't sure what to order but she definitely steered us in the right direction to some delicious food. We had sliced pork belly that came out sizzling on a skillet over glazed onions.. A type of beef rib soup which was so good I devoured the whole thing.. Also we had another dish which was recommended by her which was pictured at the bottom of the menu, yes she pointed and we agreed. Best decision made in a very long time. 
She also showed us how to eat the pork belly correctly which was very sweet of her. 
And last but not least the sides that comes with the meal was great as well there was a massive selection on the table to choose  from. 
We came there pretty late and were just having dinner I'm not sure how the service would have been with more people but I will definitely come back for the food and the sweet lady that was too kind to me and little brother.

I go out of my way to get korean food whenever I can, having spent a considerable amount of time living in korea and travelling it is always a pleasure to come across a korean restaurant wherever I am.

Cafe Ga Hyang is a lovely little mom and pop place that serves good korean food at good prices. There are no bells and whistles (good!), and yes service may be a little slow but the hospitality we were shown was wonderful.

Dolsot bibimbaps were very well done, and generous too. They are also not stingy on the banchan here, and best of all they are open until very late.

It's definitely The RUDEST service that we ever had. Please be reminded to CHECK YOUR BILLS before leaving cuz we asked the lady to provide the receipt and she said it was messed up with others. Anyway, we won't return to the restaurant for sure and not recommend to you either.

Now there aren't all too many Korean restaurants in the Northern Phoenix area and the ones we do have aren't all too stellar. But Cafe Ga Hyang blows all the others to shame! A small little hole in the wall place, but the food is AMAZING. The first thing you have to judge any Korean restaurant by are the side dishes and let me tell you...they are tasty and well seasoned! 

The champong soup was spicy, flavorful, and filled with seafood. Definitely my favorite of the entire meal! The duk boki (spicy pasta cake and fish cake) was good, but extremely spicy. So if you can't handle your spice then I would not suggest getting it. The jajangmyun (black bean noodles) are also quite delicious though not as good as what you would find in LA. However if you need your fix then I would suggest getting it here! The kung pao shrimp and kimchee je yook bokeum are also good options if you want something stir fried. 

Though we ordered a lot there are still many items on the menu that I have yet to try (though I'm sure they are all equally delicious). 

Definitely the best Korean food I've had in the northern Phoenix area. Try it...you won't regret it!

Loved this place!! Been here a few times and every time the food has been amazing! During 'busy' hours the service can be a bit slower than some like but to me I don't mind the extra time to decided on food and just relax with friends. 

The place itself is nothing spectacular but the taste of the food makes up for just about everything.

I did have the unfortunate experience of not 'eating well' during one of my visits. Its nothing bad trust me, I just found it adorable that the lady said we barely ate anything while me and my friend imagined we ate a lot. The portions are so large with all the added sides, I was proud we could finish what we did!! We had ordered the bul goki, haemul pa jeon, and jajang myun to share. The Haemul pa jeon and bul goki were both divine!! The jajang myun was good but I usually like a bit more 'spice' to mine.

This place is one of my fav. places to go now!!.

I will never return here. I don't have high hopes for Korean food in Az, but this restaurant fell far short of even my lowest expectations. The service was terrible and the food was even worse, not to mention both my mother and I felt sick later that night after eating here. There are better Korean restaurants in Phoenix if you get a hankering; no need to go here.

Gaibe is ok, good flavor, but some pieces were pretty tough. 
The seafood tofu soup is such a big let down. The portion is way to small, and it cost about 10 bucks, seriously? 
And I barely find any seafood in there, just some sad tofu crumbles...

Don't  order the soup, maybe order another bbq dish instead.

WORST SERVICE WORST FOOD
This is one of the worst korean restaurant ive been to. First of all, when we went into the restaurant, no body greeted us. We had ask to be seated. Once we were seated and were ready to order, the waitress told us that i have to wait for a LONG time to get jjajangmyeon. We asked how long and she said she didn't know since shes not a cook. Are u kidding me?? So i changed my menu to jjampong and she said the same thing. Jjajangmyeon and jjampong are their "special" menu and i cant believe  i couldnt order them..!! i might have been extra angry since im pregnant but if i knew i couldnt have them, i would have went to another restaurant. So i was looking through the menu to see what i can order and she said if i werent ready shell come back. I was taking 30-60secs to decide and she couldnt even wait that long. She convinced me not to eat jjajangmyeon and seemed annoyed to even serve us. That made me really mad so i said no wait and ordered bulgogi. Then It took her really long time to bring out the side dishes. When she brought rice, her finger was inside the bowl..!!!!!! OH MY WORD..... this made my husband angry. When the food finally came out, my husbands dish-spicy galbittang-was blend. My bulgogi was burnt. Bulgogi is one of the main dishes in korean cuisine and if a restaurant cant cook well, then that restaurant has a problem. What made everything worse was that at the end when she brought the check, she was friendly all of sudden..! She asked if the food was okay. I wanted to tell her the truth but i didnt want to talk to her so i just said its was ok. She also told us that we should call 15mins ahead of time if we ever wanted to eat jjajangmyeon. She said their jjajangmyeon is very delicious. Duh thats why we were there. I wanted to try their jjajangmyeon but i will NEVER go to that restaurant again.

No go. Roach alrert! Really last time i went there and there was german roach literally crawling over my table my wife n i was freaked out so i killed it right away and asked to worker and they said "this is not a food roach! This is a flying roach. It's totally fine."(which is same shit anyways.) And Tried to made us pay the food. I was like wow. Paid the food. No tip. Never going back there.

To the onwer. If you see a pest going on. Dont just shove them to ground. Actually care about it.
I love the food it's so traditional as well as the atmosphere! But no korean alcohol!?? I wish they had it. it would complement their food!

The food here is fantastic.  At first when we pulled in we weren't to certain about the place based on first impressions.   The server was friendly and attentive and the food was served quickly.  Three entrees ran us about $45 with tip.  We had enough left over for the next day.   Each dish was tastier than the one before it and this is a must visit for authentic korean food.

The atmosphere is great, feels very comfy and cozy. However, The soup was pretty tasteless. I would not recommend this place especially not after finding A light brown Thin, straight HAIR IN MY RICE. i knew for a fact that it was not my hair because i have dark thick curly hair. I confronted the waitress about it and she simply said "oh, sorry." And returned with a new bowl of rice. I Definitely lost my appetite and desire to ever to return to this place again.

Late nite junkie KTown cravings bring us all the way to the west side of town to hole in the wall Cafe Ga Hyang! As if entering your fave K-auntie's dilapidated hut of a dining room, we find comfort food that soothes your Asian soul. Best spot in AZ for sure!

Upon a sip of the mugi-cha, we are always swept back to memories of summer days back in Tokes. We thoroughly enjoyed the banchan dishes; faves being the daizu moyashi sprouts and marinated potatoes on top of flavorful kimchees. 

Hubby was drooling for gochujang flavored anything really throughout our Man of Steele date night and he was beyond satisfied with his kalbi dolsot bibimbap. I always order jap chae and sul lung tang cuz typically I'm halfway full from the bancha. We still had enough for leftovers and I'll be happy to heat up my leftovers for work tomorrow!

Talk about "hole in the wall"....this place is just that. Whenever I eat KOREAN BBQ I always get Bulgogi. So far this place beats them all in Phoenix. Coming from LA you expectations are high for these types of foods. Well this little place definitely left our bellys full and our palates happy! I'll most definitely be coming back. 

The only reason I didn't give a 5 is because of the outdated decor. Other than that nothing went wrong. 


Plus good to know that they are open till 2am..that's so dope:)

I had the shrimp and vegetable appetizer which should be called vegetables with two shrimp. My wife had some soup (koren name - can't write it) but she liked it. Young man took our order and didn't know what bulgogi was- working in a korean restaurant and don't know bulgogi??? Took 20 min. to get our check after we asked for it.
My second time having Korean and it met my expectations. The place looked a little dark but service was good and also food. I will recommend.

So incredibly happy to have found this place! Yay YELP!!!!  My husband and I come from NJ/NYC area where good Korean food was plentiful.  Since moving here to Arizona, we have had such difficulty finding our ethnic restaurants, including Korean restaurants. Thanks to the fellow yelpers, this small mom and pop restaurant was exactly what we were looking for since we have made our move.   And I must admit, the soft tofu soup with seafood (Haemul Soon Du Bu) was better than the ones back home.  The bimbim bap was also amazingly delicious, as was the spicy squid with veggies (Oh Jing Uh Bokeum).  The Banchan (little dishes) also hit the spot as they were all equally tasty and spicy.  The service was great and we love our waitress!  In fact, she informed us that within a couple of weeks, they will be receiving their liquor license along with karaoke.  I don't care much for the bad singing, but I am happy to be drinking Soju soon and have some Bonchon (fried Korean chicken) to wash it down with...WINNING!
Fantastic! Our first  Korean experience. Banchan was awesome. I had the Dolsot Bibimap, she had the Pork Bulgogi.

We came in tired from a long drive from Grand Canyon. But we were not even greeted.. after being seated they didnt come get our order until we finally got their attention.. they rudely told us that what we ordered was not available.. A young child in our group asked the server if he can borrow a pen to play games on his napkin while waiting for the food. She snatched the pen from his hand and walked into the kitchen. An elderly woman in our group asked for water with no ice. Server rolled her eyes and never came back with the water. Of course our food came out really late. Seriously I've never seen such rude service straight up in our faces.. overall the service was so so bad. It put us in a bad mood before we even ate the food.

I came here with two friends for dinner after reading many of the yelp reviews.  Overall, the food was decent but overpriced (although the prices were in line with many AZ competitors).  The banchan was good, roughly 8-10 dishes as other reviewers have noted, but it took about 30 minutes to make it to our table.  Also, there was a refusal to refill any of the banchans (abnormal for a Korean restaurant).

I ordered solleungtang, which was decent.  I would give it a 3/5, there wasn't much beef but the broth was okay.  My boyfriend ordered dolsot bibimbap which was below average in comparison to Gogi in regards to portion, quality, and price. My friend ordered jjajangmyun, which was clearly from a jar and not homemade.  Further, her meal arrived roughly 15 minutes after the solleungtang and bibimbap.  

Bottom line: below average on quality, quantity, and price. It gets 3 stars because there isn't much selection in AZ.  If this was located in CA, it would've gotten 2 stars or less.

My family and I decided to go here for my birthday dinner and i'm glad we did. I'm a vegetarian and had trouble finding any options on the menu, but upon asking whether or not a dish had meat in it, the two ladies who were working as waitresses took it upon themselves to help me pick a dish that could be customizable, and specially ordered the noodle dish vegetarian and without any meat. It was a totally sweet thing for them to take the liberty to do. All of the food was fresh, delicious, and most of all - authentic. Definitely the best Korean place i've tried not only in the West Valley but as a whole.

Had my first real authentic Korean food at this restaurant (I don't count the packaged rice and noodles brought in by the 4 Korean baseball players my family hosted for the Jr. Cal Ripken World Series back in the early 2000's). I was a little hesitant because not too many people were there, maybe because it was a Sunday... Nonetheless, I had a wonderful experience. The food exceeded my expectations by far. Everything my partner and I ordered was fresh and served in a timely manner. We loved it so much we came back a week later for more! Overall, service was great and the atmosphere is intimate. Portions can be split between two people, meals are decently priced. I can't wait until I move to Arizona so I can have some more of their Korean BBQ!

This is yet another restaurant that my grandmother and I visited. I had extolled about the virtues of Korean for the past year since returning from there in September 2K11, and eventually we decided to go here. The restaurant has a real cozy atmosphere and the people who run this restaurant do an excellent job of waiting on you as well as being very friendly. 

We both had the bulgogi bi bim bap and the man du guk w/ sliced rice cake and they were just as good as I remembered. This restaurant does everything right and it makes me glad that I am able to find a restaurant here in Phoenix that serves excellent authentic Korean cuisine.

I have only two minor complaints. 1. The side dishes are a little skimpy even for two people and if you want extra you have to pay more, as opposed to most restaurants in South Korea which mostly gave you unlimited side dishes, and 2. they don't let you do the grilling. You order it and they cook it like most American restaurants do, which is disappointing if that's what you are looking for. Don't let this deter you from trying this restaurant as you'll miss out on some of the best food ever.

So a few months ago I moved to AZ from Los Angeles (korea town to be specific) and have not been able to find a descent little korean restaurant, until now!  What make this place even more special is that they are (or the cook is)  Koreans that grew up in China and are able to cook both, very well. 

The place is new, only in business about 5 month. The owner also owns the AYCE sushi bar in front (which is how I found this place).  For me, walking into the restaurant was like being home.  The first time I went they were about to close but stayed open and make my food.  The owner, Sunny, was so sweet and hooked me up with kim chee and a lot of other side dishes.

I've been back a few time since and have enjoyed it each time.  I'm so happy I found my new little korean spot!

We ended up here on a Friday night close to 10pm, partly because there aren't many restaurants in the Valley open this late and partly, because we tried it before and found it "okay".  This time, I wanted to order the campong; but the waitress made it clear, in both word and facial expression, that it would take a long time to make and it was obvious she didn't want me ordering it for that reason.  That was fine.  I had instead a dish, which basically took most of what is presented as cold appetizers in multiple dishes brought to the table, except mixed together, served very hot on a bed of rice and included an egg and a little meat.  While I do enjoy the cold appetizer dishes, I have to admit, they taste better very hot.  My partner had a soup, which could be best described as pot stickers in broth.  The amount of food was copious and we were quite happy with what we got  (which was not the case the first time we came here).  The fact that neither of us are Koreaphiles and know Korean food doesn't exactly help in choosing items.  For one thing, almost every dish on the "entree" page is soup.  While I readily admit that Vietnamese Pho, for example, could easily fill you up, because everything and anything is thrown into the soup, I come from a background where soup is something served as an accompaniment to a meal, not a meal in itself.  So, mentally, a soup for dinner wouldn't cut it with me.  The 'non-soup' entrees are limited and are on the menu's back page; so don't despair if you can't seem to find items that aren't soup!

The restaurant is small and intimate.  There are a few booths made to look like stereotypical Korean "huts".  I feel like I'm in a cage sitting in one of them; my partner likes the privacy and cozy feeling they provide.  A TV plays in the background, which might be fine, if you understand Korean.  However, the scenes from a report about some hospital and skin diseases (along with a blurred image of a man doing his business at a urinal) is not really something I want to be seeing while I eat.

There have been complaints on Yelp, that they're not very attentive when it comes to filling the appetizer dishes.  I can only say, that these appetizers arrived after we were sitting a very long time and (coincidentally?) very close before the main meals came out.  Whether this is done on purpose to limit how much of the appetizers you'll eat before your dinner shows up so they don't have to refill it, I don't know.  But the coincidence seems pretty strange; especially considering other complaints about this very topic.

To sum up, while I would enjoy a bi-yearly trip here (six months ... two years ... you choose the meaning!), Korean food simply isn't something that wows me enough to make the effort to make a special trip out here ... especially from the west valley, some 45 minutes away.  The food is hearty; can be very spicy (though I didn't think overly so ... maybe I'm just very used to spicy food); and, let's face it, "basic".  I've yet to have ANY Korean food that I'd describe as "finessed" or "subtly spiced".  That may just be me.  Sushi will always get top billing with me (but not other Japanese food!); followed by Vietnamese and then Szechuan.  Korean food just seems to be something that I find "collides violently" with my taste buds and assaults the senses.  As proletarian as my taste in food can be, I just don't find enough variety in taste to make the cuisine something I can get excited over.  Add to that a small restaurant, which is very hot in summer (when we last went), crowded, not cheap and has slow service and my enthusiasm drops even more.

I don't dispute fans, who've written that this is the next best place to Inchon or Seoul in the Valley.  Like I said, I'm no aficionado of this cuisine, so I wouldn't know.  I can only say, my taste buds told me, that this food and the service in this restaurant is more "Pyongyang" than it is anything down south.

Acceptable; but no "wow"

Food is still yummy! And service is still great! Waitress is sweet. My honey had the Bim bap, his usual and loves it. I had the seafood and tofu stew, mild (u can choose spicy level), yum. And green tea mochi ice cream, hmmm hmm! Next time I plan on having whatever sizzling dish the table next to us had cuz it smelled delish!
Amazing hole in the wall! This was my first time experiencing Korean food and I went with a classic. kimchi jjigae! Sour spicy goodness.

After coming back from the grand canyon, this was the only place open.
We got there, the atmosphere was great, pretty calming.

We ordered, the wait was a bit long.... But the food was worth it.

Hello again Reviewers,
I been here recently going to give the place another try. Turns out it was a bad pick again. We waited and waited for almost a hour to get our food and ended up leaving without it. Our waitress was by herself and she was overwhelmed with a large group needing a lot of assistance. I ordered regular spicy chicken and my friend ordered pork. We waited first for 30 minutes after ordering, asked about our foods and the waitress was busy just saying 10 more minutes okay. Well 10 minutes passed and we waited again for another 30 minutes really hoping it would be done. Still nothing so we got up and started heading for door when the waitress told us that the pork is still coming just takes a long time to thaw out it's frozen. FROZEN. The pork was frozen and they had none for the night. Instead of telling us that first they made us wait till we got tired of waiting. Very poor service.

Good food but my son in law specifically said no veggies... It came on a bed of onions. We said excuse me we said no veggies she said its just onions.  I and he explained he is allergic to onions and she said just pick off the meat and dont eat the onions... 1. Umm wtf no! 2 thats a serious issue its a persons health and safety.

I've had the kalbi, bulgogi, dolsat bibimbap, haemul pajeon, and the duk bokki over the course of a few visits. All the food and side dishes are amazing. Very authentic and great service. My go to Korean restaurant in Phoenix.

This is a second visit to this restaurant, I must say I had a lasting impression of the cham pong the first visit so I decided to put it in the list of restaurants to frequent. The food tonight 2/26/13 is just mediocre, the soups are more watery than the first time. I ordered the kimchi chigae (kimchi stew) and my boyfriend ordered the cham pong. The middle aged owner brought out only pickled daikon for my boyfriend, and pushed the banchan(side dishes) to my side of the table. That was fine, but my food came first, so I offered some of my sides to my boyfriend who was still waiting for his entree. She threw us a look of distaste.

When we finish some of the sides, I asked for a refill...and she told me "We don't do refills, it's too expensive." Fine, if  she had left it at that, I would have waived it off...but she refilled the sides of the table next to us after she told me that. I've never been to a korean restaurant where they don't refill the side dishes. And on top of that I've never been to a korean restaurant where they discriminate between asian customers and white customers in the next table.

We finished our meal, and asked for boxes for leftovers. The lady shakes her head as though we shouldn't take out our leftovers and reluctantly brings us two boxes. I've never had such poor service at a korean restaurant...and I probably won't be back for this type of treatment.

I had a craving for some Korean food and decided to give this place a try. It's hidden in an old strip mall but once you walk in, it's a nice little place. Clean and well kept. There was only one server but she was attentive. I got the seafood & beef tofu soup ($8.98) while my boyfriend got the bulgogi plate ($15.99). Both were pretty good and my Korean food craving was satisfied. It was nice to see Korean families eating there too - I figure if they eat here it must be pretty authentic. Overall, we enjoyed it.

I would give this place a full five if it wasn't for some of the service. 

The food? It's amazing. Cafe Ga Hyang is a constant for me, and never fails to satisfy the craving for some delicious Korean food. The menu is a bit pricey, but know that the restaurant does give big portions and there is a 9/10 chance you'll be taking some of your meal home with you. The menu has a wide variety- from basic chicken teriyaki for those afraid to try new things, to japchae and bibimbap and a menagerie of seafood dishes for those who go to the Korean cafe for, well, actual Korean food. The banchan (small side dishes for those who don't know by now) are always tasty and from them I've discovered my love of bean sprouts. My only warning is that if you are new to Korean food, don't try to be exponentially brave. It's always good to ask questions and to listen to the servers- they have served plenty of people and know what they're saying. My first time there I ordered something at random and ignored the advice of the waitress, only to end up eating nothing because the dish was such a surprise to me and I had no idea what half of it was (nor that egg would be in it, yulk). For those who want smaller prices and a smaller serving portion, ask for the lunch menu.. which brings me to my next point: the service.

At first we were offered the lunch menu when we happened to make the time (I believe it's 11 to 2? don't quote me on that), but afterwards we always had to ask. When we did this, it was always an obvious look of dissatisfaction from the waitress before she left to get the menus, or "just tell me what you want" and no lunch menu was brought to be looked over. Well.. I was asking for the menu to see what I want to order, perhaps I wanted to try something different? Aside from this, the wait staff is friendly. You get refills often or if it's a busier day, they simply leave a pitcher of your choice of drink and you can feel free to converse without interruption. You always get a 'hello' and a 'goodbye' and if you frequent the place, they do care to recognize you as a regular. As I said, aside from the peeve with the lunch menu, I have zero complaints about the staff.

Last up? Ambiance. I always go when it's around lunch time or earlier in the morning so I've always entered the place when it's quiet. I love that they have the tables out in the open, or the much more private booths. There has never been an issue with cleanliness concerning the tables or the overall restaurant, and the tv's there make interesting enough conversation if you don't know Korean, to where you can try to figure it out (for those who care to be interested in other cultures. I find my brother is irritated with the fact he can't understand but that's just him). It's quiet. Nice. Peaceful. It's an A+ place for conversation and trying something new as long as you don't take an occasional bad attitude to heart.

Authentic? I can't believe people think this is authentic korean food, because IT'S NOT!!!. 

This place is more geared towards chinese style korean cooking. There's no such thing as dol sot(stone pot) black bean sauce dish in Korea. Yes, the black bean sauce is sometimes used to mix in rice. However, the black bean sauce is served as a noodle dish. This idea came from when you order/eat black bean sauce noodles and you have left overs of the black bean sauce,but still have room to eat and your stomach is not content and all you have is rice, you would mix the rice with the left over black bean sauce you have in your bowl. Well, that's fine. Maybe they decided to add something new to their menu....

But that's not the problem, the flavor of each dish is nowhere near what authentic traditional korean food should taste like. Even my vietnamese friend who is in love with Korean culture told me at the table that the seafood Soon Du bu (Tofu) soup was nothing like she has ever tasted. The shrimp they used is wrong. Shrimp that goes in the seafood Tofu soup should have the skin on with whiskers or whatever those things are called on the shrimps head. It maintains freshness of the soup broth and tastes 100% times better. 

The shrimp Ga Hyang used had to be frozen shrimp. They smell too fishy. The quality of the food was not good. The fish cake side dish had the flavor but it was really cold and the texture was dry. The thing that I was most disappointed about  was that my favorite side dish, the soy sauce/viniger marinated jalepeno, was sweet and gross. :( So sad... It should be crunchy and slightly tangy/sour? from the vinegar. 

Plus, it's not that hard to split checks. The lady gave a big sigh and an attitude when my friend asked for separate checks. Why ask and allow it in the first place then? I wouldn't do that in front of my customers, especially if you want them to come back. 

This just made me miss Los Angeles a lot. The korean restaurants in La outbeats any restaurant in Arizona. If anyone knows any good quality Korean restaurants in Arizona, I dare you to recommend me one. 

Till then, I'll have to make Korean food at home or wait till I go back to Cali. 

(I know I'm a harsh critic, but I'm a foodie....deal with it! :p ....and I'm korean)

We went here today for lunch and it wasn't as good as it has been in the past. I only go for the jajangmyun, and it was disappointing. It was too bland, and just lacking in flavor. They used to offer a gan jajangmyun if you asked, but today they refused to accommodate this request. The ban chan was plentiful, but they give it to you about 15 min before your meal arrives. My husband ordered the daeji bulgogi. It was dry, and also lacked in seasoning. I've definitely had better Chinese Korean food in Arizona.
Spectacular! Best Korean food in the valley. Stop by and eat at this little culinary gem. Authentic fare, reasonable prices. The kimchee soup is a must have!

So good! Real authentic Korean dining experience! Did not disappoint. The service was amazing and the food just as good! Definitely get the gyoza and the bibambap. Not many places in Phoenix have bibambap so this restaurant is a real gem! Will definitely recommend to friends and would like to go back soon
It's truly a gem! It's like eating at a Korean family's home. The chef is the owner, she is very proud of her food.

After our trip to Koreatown in LA a couple of weeks ago, we were craving some Korean BBQ! The only problem is we are not in Cali anymore and live in AZ. : ( If you are looking to grill your own meat, this place is not it. However, if you are looking for great Korean food, abundant amount of banchan and friendly service- then come to this restaurant!! We had the sweet n sour pork (not your typical Chinese food sweet n sour entree) for our 3yr old, kalbi tang, and grilled pork belly. In our previous visit we had bulgogi, kalbi, and chapjae. Everything we've tried has been delicious and reminiscent of our experience in Koreatown.

If you are looking for good service then don't expect much from this place. However, if you are just looking for DELICIOUS KOREAN FOOD especially at 11pm at night, then give this place a try! I love that this place opens up so late! 2 AM everyday except for Sunday which closes at 11pm.
Open until 2AM. Great price and food. I will come definitely come back and try many more korean dishes and kim-chi.

I've experienced better. 
Food: we ordered a few dishes (7 dishes) including kalbi and spicy seafood soup, pancake, squid, bulgogi, black bean rice, and the hot stone pot. Kalbi dish was over burn a little bit but last time we were here it was good.
It's Friday night and there was only 1 server but that wasn't much of a problem.
Our dish took a while to come out so speed rating would be around 3/5, could've been faster.
Server was friendly. 
Overall, only negative thing is that it took a while (30-35min) for foods to come out even though the restaurant wasn't busy.
Food: below average - average as compared to other korean restaurants in the area.

Very good food at midrange prices. Place is small so if you get a table, do not take it for granted! Family run business, so they take the orders and cook it themselves so do not expect phenomenal service.

Pros:
The food tasted very good. (Bibim bap & duk buki) 
The atmosphere was nice. Had private tables and nice decorations. A unique date idea if you are hungry up until 2am

Cons:
Slow service
Never refilled side dishes or water. Waved for attentions. 
Not the friendliest servers 
Only came up to us 3 times: give us menus,  give us water/take order,  give us food and check. 
Walk passed us but didn't come to us when cup was empty and at end of the table
Love this place. Very authentic and great service. Best Korean place I've been to in Phoenix.

Didn't know what to expect due to the reviews, but after our meal, I was very satisfied. Our waitress was very friendly and when we first got there it wasn't very busy. We ordered the bulgogi and kal bi bimbimbop. I'm used to Korean food in the Bay area, which is very good, and I thought it compared pretty well to what I'm used to. The little dishes that they bring to you was very tasty and authentic. I would definitely come back and give it 2 thumbs up!

I really wanted to like this place and I gave it the old college try, but it's a no from me. I came here once for kimchi jigae and was disappointed. It tasted very "off" and the banchan tasted old. In all honesty, the food actually made me ill later in the day. I was not looking forward to going back but my friends and I were craving Korean food and it was late so I decided to keep an open mind and give it another chance hoping the one bad experience was just an isolated incident. Unfortunately, it wasn't. The food was just not great again. The bulgogi was burnt and the jajangmyeon had no flavor. On a positive note, the banchan tasted fresh this time so I will give them that.The worst part of it all was that as I was paying to leave I saw a cockroach crawling on the wall. :(

Not kid friendly. No crayons and coloring books. No alcoholic beverages because they lost their liquor licence. No dessert because their freezer was broken. All in all the food was EXCELLENT! My wife had BBQ shrimp and I had the BBQ tenderloin. DELICIOUS!

This place was really good. Came an hour before they closed. The waitress was honest about our options. We ordered the duk boki, the bul goki, and the kalbi bibimbap. The duk boki was spicy! I was dying and loved it! Never had it before. The ban chan was on point.  The bibimbap came in a stone pot. It had a crispy rice bottom! Sooo good. The waitress even mixed it for me. I love these hole in the wall places! Would go back again to try the Korean bbq!!

So I was here for the this months installment of the International Supper Club UYE. I have never had Koren food before. I wondered if I would like it but I am always willing to try new things. When we arrived I questioned if I would like it again because it is in a shady shopping center in a shady part of town. But again sometimes the best food comes out of little run down shops.
When we walked in our large table was all set up for us. It took up most of the restaurant because the place is not that big. We were greeted by what seemed like the owner but was our Koren mother for the night. She was very helpful and explained what dishes were and made suggestions. She even told a few people what they ordered wasn't good for dinner and they should get something else.
We sat down and waited for the rest of the group to arrive. It was growing by the minute as people brought more people with them. We even lost two because it was getting last and still had 15 in the party. Water was passed out in glasses and also large carafes for refills. Menus were handed around and indecision struck. What do I get? Lucky Ursula D was to the rescue and let people know what was good and what she had had at other places. So I picked the Bul Goki which I am spelling wrong I'm sure and still can't pronounce correctly. It is thinly sliced beef with onions and possibly a few other things. All stir fried up. Whatever it was it was really good. Everyones orders started coming out after just a little while and they were all steaming hot. Even with 100 plus degrees outside they were still steaming. Some of up got sucked into the Korean soap opera that was playing on the TVs all around us but the food more than distracted us from it.
All the food smelled good and everyone was raving about it. It made up for the fact that there was no beer to be served and soda was served in a can. The restaurant was very nice and our Korean mother waitress owner was very nice and handled our large group with no problems. Even split the bill up easily. Which can get tough with our group. I will definitely be back to try more delicious Korean food and say hello to my new Korean mother.
International Supper Club UYE has not gone to a bad place yet.

Food is spectacular. Would be 5 stars if they had beer. I love hot food and this is hot, but without a nice cold beer to take the edge off, kind of ruined it. They used to have alcohol apparently as it is on the menu so not sure what happened.

Holy Kim chi chigae!

I think this has got to have the best soft tofu Kim chi soup. Definitely full of flavours! I love how there is tender pieces of beef in my soup and big pieces of Kim chi. The only thing I would complain about is I didn't like their choice of tofu, wish they went with a softer tofu. 

The seafood pancake is to die for! I just loved how crispy it is and oh my, can eat that all day with their ban chan. Ban chan are side dishes that usually comes with your meal and let me say this, every single one of them is extremely delicious and I couldn't be happier! 

The only thing I would be hesitant to order again is the spicy rice cake with fish cake. Don't get me wrong, the flavours were on point but for the price, they literally give you a few pieces of each...

I felt like it's a win for me because I loved everything I ordered but I did go with a party of 8 and I got to taste their food. The meats weren't amazing and one of the beef dish, I believe rib eye or something was so flavourless and tough. My boyfriend didn't really enjoy his spicy pork either. 

The service is weird. The lady serving us was nice and not nice at the same time. 

Would definitely return for some more of that yummy kim chi chigae!

You know that old saying, "Don't judge a book by its cover?" That definitely applies when it comes to Cafe Ga Hyang. 

My husband and I have been trying to find a decent Korean place in Phoenix for a while, and after less-than-stellar experiences at a couple of other places, we decided to try this place out, after reading about it in Phoenix Magazine. It was only about 15 minutes from our house; who knew? 

Upon arriving, we were a bit apprehensive; the restaurant is located next door to a tattoo parlor in a pretty sketchy, half-empty strip mall in Glendale. The decor is straight out of the 1970s, and the night we were there, the air conditioning was basically not working. But keeping in mind that "don't judge a book..." thing, we decided to stay. (We also took the fact that we were the only non-Koreans in the place as a good sign.)

I ordered the bibimbap with beef, which arrived in a sizzling hot bowl, as it should. Our server, who I am pretty sure was also the owner, asked if I had ever eaten Korean food. Before I could answer, she instructed me on the proper way to stir the ingredients in the bowl together. Almost immediately everything began to sizzle and the smell of cooking food wafted across the table! It tasted delicious, the perfect combination of spicy, savory and sweet, with a mixture of sticky and crunchy rice (the pieces that had cooked to the sides and bottom of the bowl.) If there is such a thing as Korean comfort food, this might be it!

My husband ordered the kimchi chigae, which is basically a stew made of  kimchi, pork and tofu. He was a bit disappointed that it wasn't spicier, and had more tofu than meat. I had a few bites and found it nice and savory - I will probably order it next time. The stew also arrived in a stone pot so hot it was still boiling, so while we waited for it to cool off, we helped ourselves to the Banchan, which consists of several small plates of side dishes that are served with every meal. Most of them are served cold or chilled, a nice counterpoint to the heat of our main dishes. I liked the pickled vegetables, the bean sprouts tossed with what tasted like a mixture of salt and vinegar, the pickled radishes, and the kimchi (again, more savory than spicy.) I did not really care for the steamed eggs.  Again, our server was kind enough to explain what everything was. 

All and all our experience at Cafe Ga Hyang was a pleasant one, and we will probably be back at some point. I especially think this would be a great place to come in the winter; a sizzling/steaming hot bowl of bibimbap or chigae would really hit the spot on a cold night!

Easily best Korean food I've had in Arizona and pretty much anywhere. The interior is dark, cozy, and a little funky, and it's open until 2 a.m. most nights of the week. Everything I've had to eat there has been excellent, with the wonderful flavors and textures that make Korean cuisine so interesting. The same lady and guy seem to be always working there, so everything is consistent. This funky section of Phoenix has some of the best ethnic restaurants in the Valley, including this one and Siamese Kitchen a few doors down.

Came here late night when no one else was there eating and it was the great. The food came out quickly and hot. Everything tasted very good and authentic. Even the server lady was very nice and showed us how to eat the food and also brought us a whole pitcher of water because we were thirsty. Great drunk food and will be returning soon.

I can't say enough about this place.  It's open late (but not on Mondays...watch it!) and it is good comfort food.  I always eat the Seafood Bibim Bap (Haemul Dolsot Bibim Bap) and it is excellent!  They bring you several sides of vegetable dishes, along with the main dish sizzling in a hot stone bowl.  If you like Korean food -- or want to try it -- this is the place to go.  Enjoy!

I am from Los Angeles California, which I visited it  numerous restaurants in Korea town in L.A.. I was not expecting a great tastes like my town....it was very surprise!!! Even better than many of great restaurants in L.A.!!!! All side dishes r tastes great too!!!!! Owner knows how to cook with out MSG!!!! It's AWSOME!!!!

Just average korean food. Kalbi was too dry & overall not worth the money. Kalbi Tang was also not the best. Ddok boki was just alright. The banchan was the best part of our meals. Waitress didn't want to serve us dessert so we left to get dessert else. Service was below average.
This place is amazing!! I've been coming here for years, a true "hole in the wall"! It's truly authentic Korean food! I'm Korean and I approve. The noodles are made in "house"! Everything is delish.

The best Korean Restaurant in Arizona. Coming from a place like Chicago, where Food is diverse and different, this place has everything you want. Open Late, Great customer service and definitely GREAT tasting food.  The Side dishes (Ban-Chan) are hand prepared and fresh tasting not frozen or stored like some of the other restaurants I've been too. Food comes out in a timely matter. There usually is only one server, one cook. During peak hours you may wait a little bit. But if you want to try good food its definitely worth the wait. This place is a Hidden gem Located in Glendale,AZ

Went there for dinner and food was good. I love Korean Bbq!!! The only thing that I didn't like was the bathroom near the kitchen area. Someone must have gone to the bathroom before I went and left a bad smell... so the smell of the restroom kind of ruined my experience. I know that it's not their fault but I just can't eat in a place that has a bad smelling bathroom near the kitchen area. A persons experience has to do with sight, sound, taste, and smell. This time the smell got to me.

The first time I walked in I was greeted by a cute door chime that said hello in Korean.  Inside it has the nice look of a Korean village.  Food is delicious, and I am always a fan of the side dishes.  Korean food tends to be on the more expensive side, but those little side dishes are great and the service was great here too.  If you are a white boy like me, they will automatically serve you regular water.  So, if you want a more authentic experience, ask for the barley tea that is customary for Koreans.  They will also explain how to eat Korean food, if you have never eaten bibim bap and start eating it as is!  :)  
The last time I was here service was great, but other times we had to go get the server.  Don't be shy, there isn't many people working here.
Don't mind the outside area, definitely come eat here!

Decent not great Korean food. Chodang in the East Valley has better galbi. In LA, this would be a 2 star place and I probably wouldn't go again, but this is Arizona, and it satisfied my Korean tastebuds so we'll go again if ever in the area.

The atmosphere this place has gives me claustrophobia and it's very dark. It's fairly closed off and the place looks kind of run down. This place as you can see it's run bye a korean person and the service is just as I expected ( The korean culture is very nitpicking and very straight forward ) so the service does come out kid of rude, so i expected it. So please try to understand they are not trying to be rude to you, they just are. But it's the only place to eat  ( jjajang myun) or black bean noodles here in Arizona. The noodles aren't that bad and it's fairly somewhat better than some i have had in LA
I would give it four stars the food, 3 stars for the service ( Just to let you know even though i fully understand the culture, i just still think it's a BS way to treat costumers) btw i am korean 
2 stars for the interior 
So i have to say 3 stars but i will be coming back to update this review

I normally go to Takamatsu for any of my Korean cravings. I decided I would try a new place and I was so glad I did. This has become one of my favorite after going only one time. The side dishes were so good. I got the Dok Boki and it was delicious and spicy. I would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a great place to try Korean food.

Man, I had called and placed an order for to go and the service was awful. I was hoping when I walked in, they would've been more friendly but unfortunately it didn't turn out that way. Now I just ordered the jjajangmyun noodles and they weren't bad at all. Not bad nor great. As I was trying to order side dishes, the lady I spoke to over the phone and in person was giving me attitude for trying to add the side dishes to my order even though I was willing to pay for the little dishes. This place sucked the life out of me definitely will not be back

Cafe' Ga Hyang does not disappoint. Reading the reviews on Yelp helped us choose our menu and calibrate our expectations on the ambiance and service. Thank you Jay C. for your detailed review. Tucked in the corner of a strip mall, we appreciated the clean and simple signage. Cafe' Ga Hyang feels like an Asian Mom and Pop restaurant. I was transported back to my childhood. As a lover of KPop and Korean Drama (KD), I enjoyed the entertainment on the two screens.

It was a Saturday night. My hubby and I love going to ethnic restaurants on weekend nights because they are usually less crowded than typical American establishments. There were two other tables filled with families. The delicious smells of spicy bean paste, charred meats and pickled side dishes were intoxicating.

We sat down quickly and thanks to Yelp reviews, made quick decisions. We ordered the bulgogi, spicy pork, japchae and kimchi chigae. Because we anticipated a lengthier cook time, we brought a card game "Exploding Kittens." We distracted ourselves with our family game, ignoring our rumbling stomachs. Then, the magical moment arrived, 10 banchan or traditional Korean side dishes that ranged from non-spicy, sour, sweet, salty, spicy, chewy, crunchy, soft, slimy. They prize diversity in heat, taste and texture. They brought bowls of perfectly steamed white rice. Our server initially brought three bowls of rice, we ordered 3 entrees. When the ahjumma saw my daughter in the corner, she quickly went back and brought a bowl of rice for her (Classy!). 

Why the long wait? Everything they bring out is piping hot. The grilled meats have an amazing char. The bulgogi and the spicy pork were perfectly cooked. I was curious to see that we did get more pork than beef. They were served in cast-iron hot plates. The bulgogi was tender and my family all agreed that they would like two orders the next time. My son said that he missed the grill table and me cooking for him. The spicy pork was tasty but too spicy for the rest of my family. The japchae was super generous, the flavors were alright. The Kimchi Chigae was the star for me. It was served bubbling hot. What a pretty dish! The straw mushrooms on top dressed the dish. The tofu was tender and nicely flavored. The consistency of the stew was just the right viscosity. The Kimchi and the vegetables were tender and distinctive, salty and spicy developed flavors. Sadly, because of the authentic heat level, my family could only enjoy it was rice. 

We ate heartily and had our favorite banchan. The ahjumma surprised us by asking if we wanted more of any of the side dishes, We requested more fish cake, mild cucumber pickle, and tofu with sesame oil. 

We will definitely be back. Next time, we might try the non-spicy Seafood Pa Jeon or appetizers as we build the heat tolerance among my family members.

I've been here twice. The first time was right at the beginning of the lunch hour and the second time was right at the peak of dinner rush.  The food and service was great both times.  The server greeted and seated us right away.  She was very helpful with the menu when I needed to make sure I was ordering the correct items.  The servings was huge in my opinion and came with plenty of side dishes.  We ordered the bulgogi, galbi tang, spicy pork bulgogi and the pork kimchi with tofu stir-fry.  Everything was delicious. My favorite is the pork kimchi with tofu stir-fry. I highly recommend this place.
The place is kind of dated, but the food is very delicious and authentic. The service is very friendly but not over powering. Definitely would come again if we are in town.

Wanted Korean food, decided to try this place. Got the bulgogi, roommate got the soup with dumplings and rice cake. Friendly fast service and wonderful banchan. Love the cucumber, spinach, napa, but the radish (daikon) was my favorite! Will definitely be back!

Okay, I'll admit that I was a LITTLE bit worried about this place after we pulled into the somewhat sketchy looking parking lot. But knowing that sometimes the best places to eat are the sketchiest and that yelp usually leads me in the right direction, my parents and I ended up here on a recent trip to Arizona.

We had the ddukbogi as an appetizer which had just the right amount of flavor without being overwhelming, although I think the rice cakes were a bit too chewy. But that was absolutely forgiveable considering the rest of the delicious entrees and side dishes.

The star of the meal was the champong, which my dad is EXTREMELY picky about, but he agreed that it was one of the best he's ever had since leaving Korea. My mom ordered sul-lung-tang which was also excellent, and I had the bibimbab. I would totally come back here repeatedly if given the opportunity!

Been here thrice now but our service tonight has just been horrible. Our food took more than half an hour to come and the server seemed more engrossed in watching TV than even offering to refill our glasses. Don't come here in the evenings!!. They're just really stressed and will stress you out too.
our hostess was a wonderful person; helpful and her service was great! Loved my very first experience and looking forward to revisiting this establishment.

I took a huge detour to try their Sul Lung Tang, a beef broth Korean dish that's easy to find back home in LA. Along with the Korean drama that was playing on a huge flat screen, it kinda reminded me of my mom's cooking. If this place was any closer, I would be their number one customer.

So I was really hesitant giving this review because I've been here a couple times and the people who work here are relatively nice (well, sometimes. I guess it depends on the mood of the place and how crowded it is at the moment). BUT I MUST PROTECT THE PEOPLE. Anyway, this was my go to place for authentic Korean food (though I must admit that they are sometimes pretty stingy with their side dishes). I came here on Sunday, 3/12/17 and on my way to the bathroom, I see stacked up trays of RICE CAKES just sitting there. For anyone to touch. Or sneeze on. Next to the bathroom. Near cleaning supplies. I was pretty shocked. Why would they just put it there and not in the kitchen (where it would be more appropriate)? I don't know but after seeing this, I totally lost interest in ever coming here. Just made me feel as if they don't really make that much of an effort to serve clean food. I mean, if I were able to see this, I wonder what happens in the kitchen with the food they serve. 

Oh. And I totally ordered hot water and it tasted weird. And I think I know why....

Lately I have had a bad hankering for some Korean food, but the valley sucks in numerous locations. This is my fourth Korean place and I was quite satisfied. I was about to head to another restaurant near ASU West because it was pretty good, but finally decided to try a different one. Gladly I did. 
I did not care about driving to the west valley from near the airport during rush hour because my craving was that bad. We finally get the the place and only one other table was there. We get seated and I had to get barley tea.
Browsing the menu I was pleased to see samgyupsal (pork belly) on the menu! We debated on an appetizer, mandu (gyoza) or ddukbokki. I've made the spicy rice cakes at home but never ordered at a restaurant yet, so we choose the latter. I wanted to see how HOT they really were. Bf ordered the usual bulgogi. 
We waited in anticipation for the food, and ddukbokki came first, large rice cakes and nice chewy texture. BOY! They were spicy, but sooo good. I enjoyed it as much as I could before I burned my mouth anymore. Then she brought out the banchan, nice large selection, some I have have yet to try until then. Also she brought the lettuce/onion salad with sesame oil dip and ssamjang. By this time I had to stop eating the spicy rice cakes and order a soda since the barley tea wasn't cutting it anymore.
Finally the meats were at our table and plentiful portions. I asked about lettuce wraps for the samgyupsal but she said I could eat it with without the wraps. Having not done so before, she actually helped me how to do so. I wasn't a fan of ssamjang before until she slapped it on my chopsticks and I was hooked. She also suggested that my bf try the bulgogi the same way, dipping in the sesame oil and with lettuce. 

I enjoyed the whole meal and was pleased with the quality and helpfulness of the waitress. I would go back and try other menu items without hesitation. When they say spicy, they mean spicy...my kind of people!

If someone is reading this review listen very carefully. You have a tough decision you must make if you are on this side of town and craving Korean. Cafe gang ha? Or takamatsu? Both Korean. A city block apart. Only one can rule them all... Let's go!!!

Cafe gang ha:

Positives 
 
+ stronger Korean flavors 
+more unique sidedishes 
+ has dishes you can't get at takamatsu. (Du boki being my personal fave!)
+open til the wee hours of 2am

Negatives 

- restaurant is dark boarder line eery and less welcoming
- does not have bbq in the tables 
-crappy korean soap oprahs blaring on tv

Takamatsu:

Positives

+Fantastic restaurant atmosphere bright and open
+full sushi bar in addition to your regular Korean favorites (sashimi salad is amaze balls shot out to chef John!!)
+ bbq at table


Negatives
- service is can sometimes be subpar.
***message for the white people ( they're Korean, don't expect them to come over with a fake smile asking  "how's everything tasting so far!?!? Every 5 minutes. No. This is not TGi Fridays)

- flavors are sometimes not as deep
- not as spicy as regular Korean. If you don't like spice could also be a positive.

I give both restaurants 5 stars because I love Korean good or bad! I go to both so take it from me! Takamatsu is the place you go to on a weekend if your with a companion and want to have a great night. Cafe ga hang is the one you go to during the week solo after work, just to enjoy a great meal.

This was my first time trying Korean food and it wasn't a bad experience. I ordered a BBQ beef meal that came with a side of rice. It wasn't bad at all. The restaurant was clean and it actually took me by surprise ! The setup was awesome, you really have to check it out for yourself. The reason it's not a 5 star is because the food was a little pricey, my meal was $14 and it wasn't a big meal. But overall I highly recommend this place.

My boyfriend and I were craving korean food and our go to restaurant was closed for the holidays so we decided to eat at Cafe Ga Hyang due to the good reviews. Came in for a late lunch and ordered two hot stone bowls of beef bibimbap. It was good but not great. There were about five small pieces of beef and the serving wasn't big at all. Definitely not worth the $$$. The appetizers however were great. 

Service was good. Some of the reviews pointed out that service here was terrible. It seemed like there was only one or two people running the place so obviously, service isn't going to be amazing.

A true gem for PHX and the west valley area. The owner provides an intimate experience and isn't afraid to offer insight on the best way to partake of the dishes. All the food was absolutely fantastic!
Expect to wait 30 min for your ja jiang mien. This is so ridiculous !! Their service is super slow here and they don't apologize for being slow too.

Wasn't sure about this place due to previous reviews but I was really craving Korean food. The food did not disappoint. My wife and I lived everything they brought out. I could see how some one could say the service was slow due to there only being one server but we didn't experience this at all. The server was so friendly and welcoming. When the place did full up she still made time for us. When our food came out it was rather fast. We will be coming back again but next time will be splitting one of their great entrees.

I've driven by this place for years, but the signage is so unobtrusive that it was effectively camouflaged, hiding its treasures. But I wanted kimchi jjigae and bibimbap late at night and they were there when I needed them. The presentation of the banchan always feels very special, and although they are not incredibly unique in their assortment, you certainly feel royal when eating them. Lots of little pops of acid and spice tease you and create an effective appetizer.

The actual entrees I'd only describe as "pretty good," but to be fair to the restaurant, I was there at like 11PM. They also didn't have any of the menu desserts or special drinks that we were looking for, but again: we were not really there at a reasonable hour, and they were gracious to have served us at all considering how late it was.

There's a pair of TVs blaring Korean television over satellite pretty much the entire time, which I actually enjoyed.
Fantastic food! Very friendly and open til midnight! Cash only. Affordable and big portions. Authentic.

OK, so I have searched high and low for decent jja jiang myun in Phoenix so I was really excited to try this new place.  I was kind of disappointed... it was super watery and slightly bland.  I actually prefer this to salty, but the watery broth made black sauce go everywhere while I was trying to eat it.  

I also got the dduk bok gi - a little heavy on the red pepper flakes but pretty tasty overall.  Those are jalapenos, not green pepper slivers btw.

We also tried the Tang Su Yuk which was delicious and pretty close to what I was looking for!

So ding ding ding - I want to try this place again before updating my review, but so far I think I like the Korean homestyle cooking this place offers!  I'm pretty sure their sullong tang will be much better so that's what I'll be getting next time.  :)

cham pong was delicious! i was craving for a bowl of spicy hot noodle soup and it was satisfying!
noodles were a bit soft and mushy...but portion was huge and loaded with veges. onions, seafood.  i had 2 huge shrimp with the head and shell. flavor was yums.

service was a little slow, but i dont blame the korean ajumma for working solo.  i walked inside and no one was at site.  i had to walk near the kitchen and yelled "hello" before she came out.

You just found one of the best hidden little treasures on the ass-end of Yelp, my friend. 

I need you to get excited about this... I need you to be on this same Level as me. You need to raise the volume on this one. 

You may not know, but you gunna learn. You gon' learn today...

Recommendations: uh, EVERYTHING.

My comfort foods are: Kimchi jiigae, seafood Tofu soup, seafood pancake, fermented bean paste stew, & Soon Dae Gook (Korean blood sausage). 

That one made you smile, didn't it? Yesss, Yea-ha-haa! That's what I'm talking about, I love where your heads at.

If you see something on the menu you can't read, pronounce or recognize... order it, D'uh. Otherwise, why are you reading this, go get back in line at Pei Wei, Fresh Wasabi, or Panda Express.  Those flavorless, cultureless McDonaldized versions of food. 

Now, where we're we? Ah yes, fair Warning. Be prepared for the owner. She's a bit...well, should we say, she's like...This is her restaurant & she knows it. 

She used to work down the block at Takama-what-ever-that-places-name-is, but left to open Cafe' Ga Hyang. Aaand in our estimation, no better move for food has ever been made.

She's like...

Some times, you may not even notice her, like soft background music that doesn't remind me of cats in heat, or subliminally as the Korean advertising on the wall telling me to drink more: all smiles & encouragement. 

Other times, She she may remind you of a certain North Korean dictator. 

In my experience, after refilling my glass a single time, she's told me that I drink too much water. 

Another time, she took my order & then told me to order something else. She told me I won't like it. She said, and I'm paraphrasing here, that: this is not for you, Americans. You ( I think she meant white ) won't like this. 

No big deal, she doesn't know me, or my love for everything cultural & food. 

And after I insisted, she gave me that face; You know, the one homeless schizophrenics give you when you tell them you don't have any money. The face that says you're a liar and a stupid-head. 

And that's true, I am a stupid-head, but don't say it to my face! 

Look, listen, Follow me, don't get discouraged. 

what I'm tellin ya is this: yes, she can be a pain in the ass. No, you may not understand much of anything thats transpiring. Yes, interactions may lead to inferences about your Manhood/Womanhood, threats against your safety I'm sure we're made in haste, who knows, whatever, it's Whatever. 

Just remember, why you're here. You're here because once you step into the doorway, You crossed a thin spot in reality; an invisible meniscus that Jaunt'ed (Thank you Stephen King) you to Cafe' Ga Hyang--a small eatery, on the opposite side of the globe, somewhere in mainland South Korea. 

So breathe in the air. Don't hurry through this. Friendships in culture are built over long, delicious meals. You're gunna want to take your time here.  

You're here because, in your travels, your many steps, You've kindled a love for everything Culture & Food.

You'll find it here.

The restaurant gave me an old and filthy feeling once stepped inside, but the food is authentic and fairly good! Number one favorite is the Seafood Pancake, a must try. The Galbi (bbq beef short ribs) turned out to be beef meat cut out from whole stick of rib bone, NOT the traditional cross-cut rib, that the bone was still bleeding on the plate. For $22, this Galbi is too expensive. Ojingeo Bokkemn was tasty, but this time opting noodles on the side for extra $5 was a mistake because the noodles were overcooked too soft and tasteless. The Dolsot was good but too little rice that 1/3 of the rice stuck at the bottom and burned. Overall, most of the food taste good. Don't expect service though, only go for the food except for the Galbi.

I feel in love with Korean food!! This place has never disappointed on satisfying my taste buds. I have to admit at first I didn't like this type of food, but I gave it a second chance and now all I think about is Korean, Korean, Korean, I'm turning Korean! I really recommend this place. You have to try the duk boki and kalbi dolsot bibimbap they're out if this world!

The place is a bit of a hole in the wall in strip mall but the food makes up for it. We ordered the chicken and short ribs BBQ and both were really delicious. It came with a lot of traditional pickled sides and individual rice bowls.  Will definitely be back

My favorite Korean Restaurant in Glendale area. Beat every Korean restaurant out here with their Banchans. Very authentic and home-like. The ajumma who serves there reminds me of my grandma. ;) Must visit. Sucks for no alcohol but that doesn't deduct a star point. Not the best if you are trying to compare with LA restaurants, but we are in Phoenix. Bare it. ;) I add, their dduck bok yi is the best yummmm...
This place suck. Really dirty. Almost wanted to throw up. The wait time is so long. I decided to check it out due to decent reviews. I guess there are low standards here. Avoid

I love this little mom and pop Korean place. My brother in law who is Korean, said it reminded him of home cooked style food. Which coincidentally the Chinese characters ?? that are part of their sign actually mean "hometown" in English. One of my favorite dishes there is their jajangmyeon, black bean noodles. You get a plentiful helping of noodles in black bean sauce with bits of pork. I normally have enough left over for another meal. I also really like their take on Sundae, blood sausage. Of course all of their bbq is good too.
Not impressed. Overpriced and they don't serve miso soup with meal. First and last time here. Had the kalbi ($21.95) small portion for price  and pork bulgogi which was just ok.
First time here. Service was excellent, staff very friendly. Great for authentic korean. The fermented soybean soup was awesome. I plan on becoming a regular!

Best Korean food yet in Phoenix.  They have an awesome seafood pancake and their bulgogi is great.  I love the fact that you can order the small tiny fishes, these are almost never part of the variety of dishes, but they have them here.  Great place and not very expensive.

The female owner is awesome. We pulled in around 1am after a hard night of drinking and the owner took care of us.  I let her know that we are used to the really good Korean food in Los Angeles and she accepted the challenge. She made some great suggestions and the food was wonderful. The complimentary side dishes were great and we ate it up as fast as it hit the table. She even came over and cut up our meat and stirred our food for us so that we didn't burn ourselves. Overall, a GREAT late night spot that blows away it's competition.

Stop here for lunch with my girlfriend. I ordered the seafood bibimbap and it was delicious. It was served inside the hot stone pot and i love how the rich burn at the bottom making it crispy. The seafood sauce was very flavorful. The side dishes kim chi was marinated well. 2nd time visiting this place and the owner lady was always nice and thoughtful. The price was reasonable for lunch meals. 
Will definitely come back to try their cold noodles one day.

Against all odds, this place is decent. Just expect slow service. 

This Korean restaurant is like pretty much every other - loud, quick, has Korean tv shows blasting 24/7, etc. You've probably been somewhere like this before, and that's fine. The only thing to note of any merit is the location is smaller than normal. 

The food here is good. While I have had better bibimbap and similar dishes, those available here are rather good and adequately spicey. No punches are pulled, which I greatly appreciate. The winner here was probably the soups available, but I may be biased due to the relatively colder weather. 

The service here deserves mention and half-complaint. There was one - that is, ONE- lady running the entire show here. Taking orders, refilling drinks, etc. While the place is small, this setup nonetheless still fails horribly: refills are a bit too slow, food is a bit too delayed, food sits on the counter a little too long, etc.  Thing is, despite her slightly impatient personality, this isn't the server's fault - no one could handle the volume at a place like this singlehandedly. It just doesn't make sense, and it makes the experience somewhat unpleasant. 

Long story short, the food here is good, but the service problem needs to be rectified immediately.
The food is great but the combination didn't include much entrees.

Best korean food! Best service!!
They don't use MSG.  food was great. What can I say~
I will come back this restaurant when I have a chance to visit Phoenix again..

I've been to a lot of Korean restaurants and have never received great service, so I don't ever expect to get anything more than decent service at real Korean places. 
Having said that, the service here was okay, they checked on us more than normal, but the food! It was great!! Like going to Grandmas for dinner, and she (even though she isn't mine) came out to see if we were enjoying it and even mentioned that she doesn't use msg.  We had kalbi (which is my all time fav), bulgogi, teriyaki chicken, bimbimbap, ALL of the little side dishes and got their gyoza which I'm pretty sure was rounded yakimandu...and it was all really good and not over priced.

They do add a service charge for 5 people or more, and it is because there are plenty of people that go out and don't understand that Korean food isn't the quickest and neither is the service so they leave no tip...so it's only there because too many people have been too cheap. If you want to be like that then figure out how to make the food yourself and good luck with that.

Finally I got to try many's favorite Korean place in Phoenix. Their haemul pajeon (seafood pamcake) was absolutely amazing, and that sauce.. Yummm.  Apparently their most popular dish is ddukbokki and I saw every single table (usually non-Korean) get one. Theie banchans were a little disappointing, everything was on a sour side and lacked variety in terms of flavors. And they didn't have their alcohol while it was on the menu.. Wha?! But still a great place to give a go!
