After a year in Korea, the food was dang close to what I'm used to. There wasn't anything too off the wall, like I've experienced.

The REAL deal for Korean Cuisine !

This is only the second Korean Restaurant I've been too and the other one seemed like  normal everyday American Food compared to here .
The decor is a mix of Asia , Gilligan's Island , and a disco .

We started with the OH MY GOD if your looking for SPICY fish cakes with chili sauce and added assorted peppers appetizer dish . I wouldn't say #10 Thai hot but maybe almost a nine hot since the sauce had a nice sweetness to cut the heat . I am not 100% sure if we got what we ordered since neither of us recognized anything on our plate as fish but whatever it was it really did taste good . The what we think ( and hope ) were fish cakes looked like logs of gnocchi pasta but had an unusual texture that was chewy and light . I saw slices of what looked like beef through the platter but passed on trying since they were unknown to me but my husband ate them and said they were just beef . Our server was so HAPPY and enthusiastic we ordered this dish she actually JUMPED in the air for joy . I was afraid to ask if this was what we ordered since I also didn't want to know if it was something I would never eat .

I tried what was basically chicken on a sizzling skillet with vegetables in a sort of sriracha tasting sauce . This dish was good . We were given eight little dishes of pickled sides . I found it interesting that each side really did change the taste of the meal and the anchovies with peppers made the taste change to a Thai food taste and I liked that one the best until I saw heads on the tiny fish and had to stop with that one . My meal also came with a large bowl of fresh steamed sticky rice .

My husband had the beef rib soup . The soup came out SIZZLING really sizzling . The soup seemed like a beef stock with some sriracia added and in the middle of the soup was a big beef rib the soup also had crumbled tofu in it . The soup also came with a big bowl of rice .

 Portions were big for sharing .
The food we ordered was very good. The service was good overall my daughter and I would go back.

Highly disappointed in my last meal. I was happy to have found this place earlier this year but I will now just cook my food at home. 

I was the first person in the restaurant and placed my order. Family members of the waitress walked in and became priority. They received multiple banchan right away and had food served to them after they ordered while I sat around with just barley water. Initially when I had even asked for barley water the waitress acted like it was a hassle to even have to serve it and told me they didn't have any. 

My banchan came with my meal and there were three items. A couple came in next to me and ordered and asked for cabbage kimchi and was told they couldn't have any because it didn't go with the meal. Excuse me?! As a Korean, I have never seen ANYONE been told they can't have banchan. I told the couple that wasn't standard service that is usually received from that waitress in other occasions. I asked the waitress for more banchan and in a serious tone she told me she didn't have any more to give me.

I had planned on ordering food for my husband to take home and she put the check on my table while I was still in the middle of my meal.  Her priority became watching the soap opera on tv rather than service. 

Speaking of the meal, my jampong consisted mostly of peppers. Pure disappointment. 

I felt as though I received prejudiced service. I was speaking Korean and attempting to be polite, but all she saw in her eyes was a half white person who she didn't have time for. I called my mom enraged after the meal and she agreed that for some meals you don't necessarily serve certain banchan but if someone asks for it you should oblige. 

I will not enter this establishment again.

Cafe Ga Hyang is a little mom & pop restaurant that serves up Korean Chinese cuisine as well as Korean favorites.  The decor is that of a  traditional Korean farm house with wood post & bamboo wall linings. The cafe part is the diso & koroake lights on the ceiling, flat screen showing Korean news & that annoying little door bell that greets you in Korean.  There was only one waitress who was very attitude.   The OB beer came w/ ice cold glass (+1*) but the prices (especially seafood dishes) were a little more than what I'm used to.  Since it's still a Korean restaurant 4 banchan (side dishes) were served which was alright.  

Champong (3.5*) 
Cha Jang Myun (4*)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/JCmyrBoNl2qfZ-f8I5RA3A?select=60KpxI2MBQrpnwno5h2DUg
Sweet & Sour Pork (Tang Soo Yook)  2* - sauce is off, pork is greasy & fatty.  in this case  I rather take  the Chinese version and pay 1/2 as much
Service - 4*
Ambiance - 3.5*

Cafe Ga Hyang is still better than a lot of the Korean joint in the valley so I will definitely be coming back soon.

It's funny because one of my friend said I'd rank my choices of school based on the surrounding food...and it's funny because Cafe' Ga Hyang's rating is exactly how I felt about the school I was interviewing with...just A-OK...not deserted like Erie, PA but not super crowded like DT Chicago

Everything on on point, the lady spoke korean, the korean television was broadcasting korean news, I ordered my usual to go korean spicy cold noodles (bibim naengmyun)...and it came out

voila....it even looks authentic...but one bite..OH WHAT THE F*&K....from almost a decade of korean dining experience...what did i just put into my mouth......

ok...time to pack up..get the bill, stomach down what i can and leave

We just had our first experience here at Ga Hyang last night and it was great! The food, atmosphere, and late night hour that it was open until (2am), made this feel like an authentic Korean experience (having lived in South Korea for over 2 years, it's almost unthinkable to close a restaurant before 10pm:) My Korean wife was also impressed with this restaurant too. If you can impress her with Korean food in the USA, then you're doing pretty good! Also, our server was very attentive to us and came back to check on us frequently to make sure everything was ok. Don't believe me? Check out the New Times magazine's very favorable reveiw of Ga Hyang here. http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/2012-05-03/restaurants/caf-ga-hyang-has-a-lotta-seoul/

In "the valley" where there is a plethora of faux vietnamese and kitschy chinese food, a lone beacon of light shines upon cafe ga hyang.  I'm a californian, which means i'm both a foodie and a cultural snob.  Judge as you may, I am more than happy to hide behind the cloak of anonymity that is the internet.  So here goes the experience.

As soon as we entered the glass-shattered door, we were welcomed and seated promptly by what seemed to be the waitress/hostess/owner of said establishment.  She provided menus and asked us what we would like to drink.  Pretty standard, really.  

Upon brief inspection of the menu and realizing we are new to the restaurant, we tested the classic dishes of such an establishment: bulgoki and japhae.  After ordering, we were greeted with traditional banchan: kim chee, pickled cabbage, cucumber salad, pickled tofu skins, pickled radish, dehydrated fish, etc.  The banchan as well as the service was both timely and fantastic.  

The japchae and bulgoki were as expected.  The bulgoki was NOT ribeye or some prime cut of beef but passed as both tender and flavorful.  The japchae was not exceedingly oily but passed with flying colors.  The banchan really was the highlight of the lunch.  The variety and quantity really warranted a repeat visit.  

I'll end with a world to the locals.  As far as authentic korean cuisine goes, visit this place.  It is authentic as you can get outside of large korean communities.  It may not be the best, but it is likely the best in the area!

Keep in mind I've given this place a 5 star review only to offset the poorly rated reviews provided on yelp.  Compared the the establishments in Seoul, Korea or at the very least those at Incheon, this place pales n comparison.  But as far as Phoenix is concerned, this place is lightyears ahead of it's time.
Excellent side dishes. I come here every Friday night. Soondae soup is excellent. This restaurant open late till 2Am. It's good for me. Now gah yang is my favorite restaurant.

This is probably the only good korean restaurant in the valley. 

Theyre kind of stingy about togo boxes and wont let you take too many side dishes home.

The lady talks to much but the food and the atmosphere is great

The interior is very cool - all dark wood and bamboo and it is spotless! My husband and I both loved our dinners. I had the Dumpling  Soup and he had the Bibim Bab. The little, complimentary side dishes are yummy as well. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit here.

Great little family owned restaurant.  We are so excited that we don't have to drive to Mesa for good Korean food!  The woman who helped (possibly the owner?) us was very friendly and attentive. The food was excellent and comparable in price to other Korean restaurants.  They also have great green tea ice cream. :)

Pretty dumpy Korean place, dirty and sticky tables and like other commenters said, food isn't that great. I'm not surprised that others said this place was dirty as well. I'll just have to come to terms that I can't have Korean food when coming through Phoenix.

This restaurant is in major need of a cleanup.and needs to be updated ceiling falling out go to the bathrooms and find food just sitting next to it on the floor that's just what I can see I wonder what the kitchen looks like.(don't want to know)
Food is just ok service is the worst with the little troll old lady/ owner always looking so stinky and in  a bad mood If I where you save your money and go to the new all you can eat Korean bbq place Gen in Tempe market place 
Just my option

Good side dishes.
Duk Boki great appetizer. 
Champong is HUGE!!

Cute little mom and pop shop, a little slow, but still good place. 
I was there mid week for dinner and it was packed!

I have lived in Korea and was looking for something to even compare to the delicious food I had there. Looking for more than just Korean bbq, I was pleasantly surprised to find this place on Google. My first time in I ordered the jajangmyeon and nengmyeon. Absolutely delicious! The ddeokboki is great, as is the bibimbap, mandu, etc, etc. 

The only reason for docking the star is really only 2 halves of different gripes. The service can be a lil eh sometimes, so that's just 1/2 a dislike. But the menu has alcohol on it, and then they say they don't serve alcohol! 1/2 of a bummer. But the food is bomb and definitely worth going to.

Like all fresh Korean food, it did take a bit to make, but the food itself tasted amazing. I haven't been able to find a place that tasted like the food I ate in Seoul, until I came to this place. I'll definitely come back

I'll be honest and say I have no idea what I ate, but it was filling and delicious. (Brief English descriptions and pictures available). It sort of looks like mud but I can guarantee it tastes much better. It was some sort of seafood bean sauce rice stone pot and the last item on the lunch specials. The boyfriend would give it a three for his dal bulgogi. It was good, but nothing to write home about and I would agree with his food rating. The sides were of varying delicious rating with our favorite being the tofu which we fought viciously for.  Korean expert said this location is good with quality meat and his favorite tofu soup. I'll take his word for it.

Was impressed with the food, the Beef Bulgogi has a smokey flavor which I've never experienced before but was very good.  Service was great, waitress had a smile and we enjoyed our Saturday afternoon meal.  The serving sizes were great and the amount of side dishes were plentiful and a great variety.  Traveled from Surprise, AZ and will make the trip again.

We go here a lot because of how late it is open and because I think it's better food than at OHYA up on Thunderbird. 

The low rating is because of service.. It's a hit or miss. They have only like two women working here and its one at a time. If you get the older lady you will get terrible service. 

Like us. Right now.. We have been sitting here for 30   minutes after she threw the menus at us without making eye contact to run to a bigger group of people. We put in our order but it's been over 30 minutes of nothing.

This is our first time here, we had bulgogi and it was the most authentic Korean bulgogi I've had. The customer service was also good. The only problem about this place is the A/C, so we moved one of the fans to where we were sitting. The overall experience of this place was good.

Super delicious! We stopped in one night, unaware of their extended hours. We were the only two in and thought they might be closing soon for the night. However as we wrapped up our meal others started pouring in and we saw that they quickly filed up at 10 at night! 

Definitely a hole in the wall spot but a good find none the less! We will be returning.

My favorite Korean restaurant in the valley to eat.
Nick does a great job cooking and the food & service is always great.

This place is a little hard to find but it is located in the northwest corner next to the dry cleaners.

Been going here for years. 

Bill K.
AR4STAR AKA Skinny fish

I love Korean food. This place was awesome. They spoke Korean which was nice, nothing lost in translation then. but they also speak fluent English as well. I has the black bean paste noodles and they were the best i have ever had. Service was typical for a small cafe style. every time i go there is only like two other parties there. The food is top notch and the service is fine. They very traditional Korean dishes and actual Korean beer! Tables give you seclusion which i like. atmosphere is very nice, i feel like i could spend a couple of hours there eating and drinking

Really a great little place.  Food was extremely good. Service was good.   Small kitchen and only 3 people one cook and one helper plus one lady serving plus she busses dishes. When busy I am sure service gets slow but worth the wait.  The cleanest bathroom I have been in in a long time.  Tells me kitchen is same way   Do not miss this place

This was our first visit to Cafe Ga Hyang and enjoyed the everything we ordered, including spicy ddukboki, mulnengmun with Kalbi, and dolsot bibimbap.  The server warned us that ddukboki will be very spicy.... and it was....and we loved it.   

Kalbi was very flavorful. Steaming Dolsot bibimbap had several different vegetables that I liked and it was sooo delicious.   The burnt rice in the bottom was also yummy.   

Great food. Good service.  We will be back soon.

Omg the tofu soup here is so good  I think its the best one I had yet. Even the condiments were flavored well. I loved everything about this store except for the service. Our waiter was super nice but it took awhile for our food to arrive. Overall I'm definitely coming back to this place. Plenty of parting spots, good food, and good service.

Price: $
Experience: 4/5
Food: 5/5
Service: 5/5

This mom and pop shop is a bit endearing. There is one waitress (presumably the owner) for the entire place so when there's more than 2 parties at the restaurant, service is bound to be slow. There were about 3 parties, including ourselves, at around 8pm and it took about an hour for our food to arrive. The Ban Chan she prepared for us sat at the front counter for about 25 minutes because she was so caught up with taking order and running around the place. We ultimately refilled our own teas and served ourselves in order to free her up some time. You can't blame her because it's a one man show, but at the same time it's a bit silly they haven't hired someone to help by now. 

The food is decent. It's certainly not four stars, and I'm not comparing this to Los Angeles. For those who have been to Honeypig in MD/VA, I think the meat there is better. 

Lackluster Dishes:
-Bugolgi 
-Pork Belly
-Japjae 
-Seafood Bibimbap 

Decent Dishes:
-Seafood Pancake
-Seafood soup (Sundubu jjigae)

Café Ga Hyang was the placed picked for the 5th meet up for the International Supper Club UYE, and I have to say I am extremely thankful for all those who attend!! You guys are amazing!!! Thank you!!

Ok like I said Café Ga Hyang was the placed picked, and when I originally called to make reservations for the group, I requested 14, but by the time it was dinner, we had grown to 18!!! Had to have an extra table added to us! Café Ga Hyang was helpful in that and didn't really make a fuss about it!

This was my 1st time ever for Korean food, so I was very unsure of what to order, so after looking at the menu I decided to go with Bul Goki, which was sliced beef marinated in a soy sauce base of sorts on a bed of grilled onions, came with a side of steam rice too. In my head I was thinking oh this is like fajitas and I like fajitas. The dish came out piping hot! And I have to say, it was very good!

Our server, whom I figured was also owner, was kind of gruff, not so much with the amount of people, just with everything I guess, but sometimes she would come across mad and not listening to you, but then friendly and helpful. I just was not trying to rock the boat haha, the little side dishes came out and she placed them on the table but told us not to eat them, they are for when our food comes out, but some tested the gods and took some of the tofu before our food came out, we were making jokes saying the soup nazi will kick you out! 

Over all it was a great experience, I would go back and try different dishes, everything looked amazing! it was a great meet up  for the International Supper Club!

We had 13 of us and it was nice they told us to come at 7:30pm on a Saturday so they can set up for us.  When we got there we still had to wait 15 mins.  It was cold outside!!!  We finally got in and noticed they only had 1 server for the whole place to do everything (ordering, busing, serving, etc.).  The service was slow but she is really nice.  The food took FOREVER!!!  I got gyoza, they were ok.  I got the dumpling with rice cake soup.  It was not that flavorful.  So bummed...

My husband and I had never tried Korean food before, so we did a Yelp search and tried this one, based on the ratings. It is a small restaurant run by a couple of older Korean women. We had to wait awhile to be seated due to limited seating and service. Once we were seated, one of the women helped us pick what to order from the menu with her limited English. We ordered the bibimbap and bulgogi. We waited awhile again for the food. When the food finally came out, I was apparently eating my bibimbap wrong, and our server kindly helped me stir in the right things and showed me what to do. I appreciated it. The food was yummy and came with a ton of sides. It was fun to try and I would definitely go back again.

Pros:
-Yummy authentic food.

Cons:
-Slow service and limited seating.
-Location.
Lol, 2 am is tentative/subjective.We tried to walk in at 1240 and they turned us away.. There were lots of people inside so it's not as if they could close early either.

Cafe Ga Hyang is not only one of the best Korean restaurants in Phoenix, but one of the best eateries in the city period. Phoenix sadly lacks restaurants that are open past 10pm, and Cafe Ga Hyang fills that void, staying open until 2am. 

My husband and I went around midnight, the restaurant was quiet but not barren. I love the entire set up, with private canopied tables on one side of the restaurant. Sitting there felt very intimate and comfortable. I ordered the Kalbi Dolsot Bimbim Bop and my husband ordered the dumpling soup. Both dishes were fantastic! Lots of amazing spices and unctuous flavors. We both loved it! At the end of the meal, I wanted to get ice cream and ginger ice cream was recommenced. It was the most delicious ice cream I've had, possibly ever, and was the perfect way to end the meal.

Before we left, we chatted a bit with our waitress (owner?) who gave me a hug on the way out. Very sweet lady!

We will be coming back and recommending it to everybody!

This was my first time eating Korean food. I thought the experience was great. I was initially a bit skeptical of trying it out. It I thought the Kimchi was delicious. I have a brother who lived in Korea and he commented on how authentic the food and the experience was.

Really awesome and renews my faith in food. Comfortable, very busy, actual Koreans eat here. A place to take you time. This is not a quick serve place and you have no reason to hurry. Please try the pickle condiments with your food. The seafood pancake is delicious but you definitely do NOT a side of rice with it.  My chicken BBQ served over raw onions may seem strange but eat bite if chicken was enhanced by it. You want to eat here. Just remember the owner lady is formidable so don't be an idiot. She is my hero.
Auntheic Korean at its best, ordered duk bok ki, kimchee chigae, galbi followed all the sides. Flavor was all there and the spiciness was perfect, service is great. Will be back for sure.

Seriously go to takamatsu only half a mile away. BEWARE! They are rude, foods only ok (I spent a year in korea) and they turned the lights off on us. Please I beg anyone here to do takamatsu or if your hankering for late night sushi do Ohya. 

Service was bad, I got bulgogi and it was bland and not flavorful at all. I also had the spicy fish cake, it came with only rice noodle and no fish cake! They never came around to refill our water, and turned the lights off.

Very nice Korean restaurant. The owner old lady is very nice. Their complementary side dishes are very good. The beef brisket is a bit too done and dry. It could have been better if it was a bit more raw and let it cook on the skillet. Their red bean ice cream is probably the best dessert I had in a long time.
Just got off the phone with Nick Rocha --- I wanted to call him and congratulate him on such a fantastic job with this business.... this cafe is amazing.

I was told by some of the review that the service was usually under-staff and not so good, however,I came very early today and I will say it was very friendly to us today.
The complimentary appetizer were various options and the staff refilled the favorite three for me.
We ordered the ribs Binbim Bap which was soooooo good, I think it was better than what we had somewhere else in town. The only con I will say is the rib meat was not in generous portion. 
We also ordered the bulgogi which was very flavorful, except the meat is bit of dry. 
We were quite curious about the Sundae, will try it next time for sure!

My friend and I were in Phoenix for just a day and wanted to eat Korean food (long story).  We found Cafe Ga Hyang online and took the 25 minute drive over there.  Walked in the door and the first thing the lady says to us is "Cash only!"  No greeting, no nothing.  She then said that the credit card machine was temporarily broken. 

BS.

We had read that others had had the same experience.  Apparently, this is routinely the way the greet certain guests, perhaps certain guests of a particular ethnicity.  Who knows, who cares; we didn't stay, drove back to the part of town we were staying in, and found a cute Italian place that was just great, and about which I shall now write a Yelp! review.  Stay tuned . . .

We went with friends who frequent this restaurant and love it.  It was worth the drive from Downtown Phoenix.  I had the cold noodles bowl and my husband had the hot rice bowl (don't recall the names).  I have been enjoying leftovers for the last two days.

This was an amazing restaurant!  I have never really had Korean food in a restaurant before.  When I was a kid a friend's mom would make me Korean food, but it's been 20 years.  Because I've never ordered Korean food, I became quickly aware that I had no idea what I was looking for.  I read through the menu and picked what I thought would be best for me.  When I ordered it, the waitress shared that this was not a good choice for a "beginner".  She suggested another type of Bip Bim Bap- which was exceptional!  Our group also ordered gyoza and another appetizer (can't remember what...) the gyoza was amazing!

The restaurant does not currently have a liquor license, so their menu is incorrect, but the staff will tell you this right away.

Came at 1 am , STARVING. 
They close at 2 am; clearly the signs says it as well. 
There must not have been any customers tonight because as we were pulling up and entering, they turned off the open sign and saw their feet shuffling away. I scoffed in dismay, they looked like they were hiding from the cops lol.

The door was open so we peeked our heads in and asked if they were open. They were pissed and the cook forcefully  waved his hand in ANNOYANCE.

The girl asked us "how many" ... If it'll be worth it for them to stay and serve us.

Horrible treatment to their customers. This is not the first time we've received attitude from them for eating late. Will not be back, no grilling anyways.

I was initially hopeful about this Korean restaurant given the number of positive reviews, but several dining experiences have given me a perspective on a number of issues that could be challenging to Korean cuisine enthusiasts. Located in a strip mall, parking was plentiful on each visit, but the interior also undesirably smelled like the dry cleaner next door. Interested diners can expect a dim lit, antiquated, and vertically arranged interior. The decor consisted a large TV, casual atmosphere, and a number of booths and tables on either side of the wall. 

The Bulgoki ($14.95) came with marinated beef that sizzled on a bed of onions. The marinade was decent but not spectacular. The beef came in too small pieces, and most tasted grainy and weak in texture. Portions were good, but the price was also too high for the quality. 

The Daeji Bulgogi ($13.95) came with marinated spicy pork, onions, and green onions. The seasoning was again decent, as I had much better elsewhere. It lacked the big juicy spicy pieces of pork that I was expecting. Not worth the price either. 

The Kabli Tang ($11.95) came with beef rib soup. The soup had decent depth, with large bulky beef ribs embedded. The soup could use some turnip to add on a sweet dimension. 

The Yang Ji Tang ($11.95) came with hot and spicy beef tripe soup. The broth was thick and milky, but lacked the deep bone marrow flavor. There were plenty of tripe, but most were also overcooked. 

The Kalbi Dol Sot Bibimbap ($11.95) came with rib meat, an assortment of veggies, egg, and hot stone bowl. The pieces of beef rib were delicious, but the rice weren't completely charred at the bottom. It was again a decent fare, given the few alternatives in the area. Interested diners should withhold their expectations, and expect some very basic flavors that were on point, but also mediocre when compared to their counterparts in other parts of the country. 

In short, Arizona deserves far better. We were provided about eight banchan items on each visit. They usually withhold these dishes until the food was served, and larger groups were consistently given more banchan items than the smaller tables. Once I saw the ahjumma visibly arguing with a couple and refusing to refill their banchan, which I thought was unusually petty when compared to other Korean restaurants, and counterintuitive to developing a loyal customer base. Another time Santi and I invited an out-of-town friend to dine here, and were completely embarrassed when she received an unsolicited lecture from the Ahjumma on how to eat Korean food. Consistent with these observations, our service each time was either slow, abrupt, or completely absent. 

Seongbukdong remains the standard for home-style Korean cuisine for me. Given the lack of alternatives in the area, all those looking for a relatively better fare should try Gogi instead.

This place never fails to satisfy my craving for a "home cooked" Asian meal when I'm too lazy to cook. The people who work here are always so nice and helpful when I'm eating the food incorrectly (they will just jump in and mix up your food if they see you haven't and you're struggling), which is very endearing. This is a small place in an otherwise "sketchy" looking plaza and is located next to a tattoo parlor and a carniceria. It's pretty hard to spot if you've never been here, so keep your eyes peeled!

I absolutely love this place!. It was great food and amazing service. I wanted a place to eat late at night and I found this little gem and decides to go with my sister as we are both Korean food fanatics. It can't get any better than this. I will definetly be back!

Great place for some Korean food. The restaurant is so cute inside, and offers some privacy in between tables. The couple of times I visited, it was pretty quiet, with only a couple tables. 
I had the bulgogi, and it is the best bulgogi I've had in Arizona. Hands down. Awesome flavors, and great portion size as well!!
I had the spicy rice cakes as well, and it was delicious as well! So good that I wish they had more. My boyfriend normally doesn't eat the spicy rice cakes, but he ate half of the dish here. 
He got the kim chi chigae, and he liked it a lot. I found it to be a little too sour for my taste. 
Overall, we felt that visited a Korean home and had some authentic Korean food. Our server was very nice and friendly as well.

When you first walk into this place, it definitely fits the description of a hole in the wall restaurant. They don't have the best decoration or ambiance. There is Korean TV running in the background (luckily with subtitles). The A/C seemed like it wasn't working full power, they had multiple fans around the room and it was still pretty warm. 

Our waitress was a very nice lady. She didn't talk much but had a very nice smile on her face and she was quick and left a pitcher of water on the table. I think prices are a little high for the location and that is the only thing that maybe I wouldn't expect from a whole in the wall place. What do I expect? Cheap and delicious food. And the food definitely makes it worth it. 

We ordered the Bulgogi and a glass-noodle-with-beef dish. They both tasted fresh and flavorful. Portions were generous and I even had left overs for my next days lunch. The Korean sides were definitely some of the best I have had so far.
I finally located good Korean in Arizona! We had bulgogi, gyoza, chicken teriyaki and spicy octopus. Everything was delicious. The kimchi and potatoes were amazing. We plan on returning.

I haven't had Bibimbap in over 3 years... and I decided to try out Cafe' Ga Hyang, and of course ordered Bibimbap.  The very first touch upon my tongue instantly burst open my appetite so large that I was willing to kill the last unicorn on earth to get another bite.  The flavor was perfect, the vegetables fresh, and the meat was charred to perfection.  This place is amazing, and the tofu soup was bubbling hot and tasted better than a kiss from a beautiful girl.  I will definitely return to Cafe' Ga Hyang.
This is authentic Korean food.  It's delicious and the prices are right.  You want Korean food, this is the place to go.  Most of the food is spicy.

Awesome food! Very traditional and service is fast. They give a lot of side dishes which is always a sign of a great Korean restaurant. I've been there about five times and have never been disappointed. Prices are pretty decent too. Highly recommend the kimchi chigae.
Food was not bad. Service was lacking. Although liquor was on the menu, they had none-with no explanation.  If this is Phoenix better Korean restaurants, good thing I'm only here over night.

We were on a road trip to San Diego and my lil son was eager to eat Korean food. Personally I do not go to Korean restaurant because they are quite expensive and not that tasty- I prefer homemade Korean food. When we visit there, the first impression was not good enough but the food! it was soooo good. All the side dishes were precious. I mean those are not something you can have even in Seoul. The lady proudly mentioned that most of veggies are grown in her garden. very fresh and yummy.

Been there a couple times and the older lady has been rude every time but we would still go because the food was good and it's open late so it's convenient to us. I noticed she was only nice to the regulars and really rude to everyone else. The tv is really loud in there and there is never has music which is annoying. I rather listen to Korean music than talking. The whole atmosphere isn't the greatest. We have been there 4 times and yesterday will be the last. When we got there we asked for water and she came back to asked what we wanted and we asked for two sodas and she got upset and said "you already have water". we said we wanted both and she walked away. I was confused on why she got mad that we asked for sodas...We are paying for it. She didn't even let us order the food. When she came back with or sodas I told her what I wanted and my boyfriend wasn't going to get anything and she gave us a dirty look like why did you guys even come. Very uncomfortable. Then when she brought me my food she just tossed/threw it on the table rushed.  The food never would get me sick till last night and I'm sure it was because of her bad energy when she did that. Then at the end I was kind enough to put the plates and everything nice and stocked up on the corner of the table to make her job easier and when brought us the check she just left a wet rag on the table like we weren't there instead of waiting until we left. Extremely rude! I can't say this enough! I told my boyfriend not to even tip her and she heard me then she was being semi nice all of a sudden...he did tip her cause he's nice but personally I wouldn't. Like I said never going back again! I never write reviews and it's sad that this is my first one and it's negative but I rather people know so that they won't have a negative night instead.

The food here is absolutely superb. I've had quite a bit of Korean food and this place trumps it all. Most importantly, the food is very fresh and authentic. I ordered the Bi Bim Bop and was not disappointed one bit. While the interior is a little dusty and the service is a little slow, the food is totally worth it! I would definitely recommend this place to anyone seeking excellent Korean!

They have a new and improved menu and added more Korean dishes. Very good!!! I've been there 4 times since they added the new menu, and it's been good every time. Very authentic Korean food. This is my favorite spot now!! 
The dishes I had so far:
Champong, Bulgogi, Sul-lung-tang, Neng-myun, Galbi, Yukgejang. All were very good. I can't wait to go back and try other food! Neng-myun (cold noodle) was especially good on muggy hot summer days.
Delicious, authentic Korean food, quick service, prices  reasonable, clean restroom, highly recommend!
Ok food, but when an adult German cockroach (Blatella germanica) struts up and walks over your napkin on the table, right next to your plate, you know the restaurant has a serious infestation.

Killer food! Every time I go. Best Korean restaurant in the Phoenix area. My father lived in S. Korea for 20 years and he told me that this was the best out of 3 or 4 others that we tried together. Super authentic!

This is my favorite Korean restaurant in the Glendale area.  When I have cravings for soft tofu soup and good variety of small side dishes, this is the place I would go!  Ingredients taste fresh and kimchi is marinated very well. Very friendly service and takes all major credit cards!

I am figuring out slowly that Korean restaurants are far and few between here in Phoenix.  Considering the slim pickings here, I'd say this is pretty good.  Not Korea Town good but not bad.  I had the duk mahn du guk which is the Korean Dumpling Soup with rice cake.  Good and simple.  BF had the Kalbi and he loved every bit of it right down to the sucking the meat off the bones.  
Decent variety of ban chan but other reviewers are right - they don't refill.  Wha?!  That is a first for me!  I had to do a little persuading for the waitress to refill one of the dishes.  So when you do ask for a refill, choose wisely.  If the waitress didn't refill, I would have given it 3 stars just for that reason.
Will be back again though to try all the other dishes.  The fact that they have Soon dae guk (pork intestine/blood sausage) is a reason for me to think it's pretty authentic and legit.  I don't see that often and was surprised to see it here.  WIll have to see how good it is next time.
But beware, we went in and the bf tried to order a beer and she covered up the alcohol section and said they were out.  Korean restaurant...that is open until 2 a.m....that doesn't have alcohol...HUH??!! Is that possible??!!
Came here for late food and to study. Servers sat at a table and talked about me/laughed at me till I left. That's it

love this place.
don't expect great service, since they only have 1 person doing most of the things. taking order, clean the table, bring food to the table, fill the water and casher.
but so far, their food has been consistently good. I have tried a bunch of their dishes, so far. quite satisfying (for phoenix area).
still can't compare to what I had in the bay area. (snob...) but it is useful as a guidance standard. come here and can't go wrong with the korean food.

worst service ever, the older lady was so rude, she could not let me take more than 2 to go box to pack my food, and the boxes were so tiny.Also the other lady, I gave her $46 including the tips, she ended up saying that I only gave her $41, the bill was $39. Was so upset about their service. Another time, my friend and I went there for late night meal, we asked for more napkins, the older lady told not to use TOO MUCH! That's not how you talk to your costumers. NOT coming back again.
Friendly talkative, attentive staff. Best Korean food I have ever had. Planning a trip to Korea next fall and this food is as authentic as it gets in America!

I really liked this place. Me and my group went there and ordered a bunch of stuff to try. Everything was delicious. The people I was with were eating Korean for the first time and they were pleased. That's all I wanted and I'm so glad that this place was able to do that for me. (also, it's pretty authentic because Korean people were in there enjoying the food as well.)

Deserving a solid 4 for the food which trumps any other consideration on Yelp, I deducted a point for slow service on a Sunday afternoon while waiting to fly out of Phoenix. As a Korean American, I can smell out good dishes at most Korean restaurants. The jjajjang myeon -Chinese brown sauce noodles -were the feature dish though you wouldn't know it except for the Korean-Chinese description of the restaurant. The Chinese have lived in Korea as a minority community since at least Ming times as refugees from the Mongols. The Chinese food in Korea -aka Korean-Chinese food is a slight variation of Northern Chinese cuisine which is based on wheat and noodles over rice. Jjajjang myeon is a close sibling to Peking sauce noodles and this version was excellent with noodles made fresh on premises and cooked perfectly al dente. The tang soo yuk -a kind of sweet/sour dish with batter fried pork or beef was different from the usual presentation as it used fresh fruit -lemon and berries -to enhance the acidity. The meat was a little tough but overall great. I had the naeng myeon is a cold noodle dish with chewy capellini grade buckwheat noodles and a cold beef broth that is vinegared and garnished with sliced radish and beef was excellent. The kalbi was presented with a 3 inch section of beef rib with the tender meat cut into bite sized chunks was savory and very soft but a little too sweet -most people (non Koreans) will LOVE this dish. The ban ch'an -the side dishes were average but clean and fresh. 


Don't go here for atmosphere -they have several flat screens running K-drama and the evening Korean news cast. The food was slow -the chief had to make a fresh batch of noodles apparently but all the main dishes were perfect. 

I wish we had more of these in Cleveland.

In addition to the waitress handing us the more expensive dinner menu every single time we arrive during lunch hours and giving us the comment that not everything is on the lunch menu, they still have soju and beer on menu, but aren't serving. We were told that they used to serve these... Ok, so did they lose their license? Big thing for a Korean restaurant to NOT have Soju...
Went while on travel for work. I got the spicy rice cakes, tofu soup and hot tea. Service was good but tofu soup was kind of bland.

Wow, what a yummy dinner! For the Yelp ISC UYE this month our fearless leaders Ursula and Monica selected Café Ga Hyang and what a great choice it was. I decided to be brave and order the octopus with noodles however our waitress (who I deducted from her brazen attitude is also the proprietor) talked me into the squid instead (sans noodles). The squid turned out to be a great choice since it was delicious! It was pretty spicy but not so much that it made your mouth hurt. Just some good heat and fantastic flavor. My hubby and mom accompanied me and to my surprise they both enjoyed their meals from the bbq section of the menu. Hubby got the spare ribs and Mom got the shrimp. Those two plates were not spicy but had really good flavor as well. In addition we all got white rice and all the usual Banchan (side dishes) including Kimchi. I did not sample all of them since it was just a ton of food but my favorite was the tofu dish.

The three of us agreed that the best thing we ate that night was the appetizer I ordered. Unfortunately I forgot the name but it was basically a plate of small, round, shrimp dumplings. The description in the menu said they were fried but they weren't super greasy or breaded or anything so I think they mean pan fried and not deep fried. They had the sweetest tasting shrimp in them and the wrapper just tasted like butter. They just melted in your mouth. The sauce that accompanied them was also delicious and unlike anything I had ever had before. It was red with a color and texture almost like tomato sauce. It tasted like it had some chili in it but it was sweet and also had some garlic and other savory flavors in there. It was so delectable that my mom wanted to keep it to put it on her bowl of rice that came with her entrée but our server informed us that was not the right way to eat it.  Too bad, because that sauce was fantastic!

Café Ga Hyang has really made me a fan of Korean food and if it was closer to where I lived I definitely would be back. A huge thank you to this restaurant for being so accommodating for our large group and making it a fabulous experience!!!

I have been here twice, once when it was very busy (Wednesday at 6:00 PM) and I got their last available table and again (Thursday at 5:00 PM) when we were the only ones in the restaurant other than the staff.  The first visit I dined alone and due to the crowd it took 5 minutes to get my menu and another 15 minutes to place my order and then 15 minutes to get my food.  I thought this was reasonable due to the fact that there was only one server but I also believed they were understaffed. While waiting I decided the decor appeared worn but clean and the TV was a bit of an annoyance.  I would have preferred traditional Korean background music and the pictures on the wall of the food and their descriptions may be of interest to others but not my cup of tea, to use an overburdened metaphor.  Speaking of tea I ordered a pot of tea and received a piping hot green tea that tasted like swamp-water.  For me this is a good thing.  I ordered the Duk Boki for my appetizer and it was a nice portion with finger size solid noodles in a bed of spicy chili sauce with what I believe were mustard greens.  It was very satisfying and had a nice sweat inducing burn.  My entrée was their Bul Goki and it was the best I ever had with a light sweet soy on the front and a smoky finish.  The beef was tender, moist and high quality served over grilled onions and a side bowl of rice.  It also came with seven side bowls of Banchan many I never had before and all of them were delicious.  I returned the following night with my son and we were seated immediately and given our menus with our order placed quickly.  Our food arrived almost immediately and we split an order of shrimp dumplings that were also the best ever.  Eight of them came with a side of soy seasoned with a heavy dose of garlic, ginger and other ingredients I cannot identify but enjoyed very much.  They were also grilled which I liked and larger than others I've had elsewhere.  This time my entrée was the Kalbi which are their Korean barbecued Short Ribs and again the smokiness and seasonings were delicious.  My son had the Bul Goki at my recommendation and he also enjoyed it very much.  We received about nine bowls of Banchan with a couple different variations from the other night.  It was difficult to determine which I preferred they were all so good.  To summarize I would give Cafe' Ga Hyang 5 stars for their food, 4 stars for the service and 3 stars for the facility and price.  I will definitely return for more of their epicurean delights.  NOTE: Cafe' Ga Hyang no longer serves any alcohol.

Coming from Los Angeles, I guess I shouldn't have expected the same type of food. My friends and I visited this restaurant for lunch on a Sunday afternoon, and we were all craving Korean food. 

We sat down, and the waitress was really friendly, especially after finding out we were also Korean. She hooked it up with lots of side dishes (banchan). 

Food was good overall, but I was unable to eat the neng myun. I'm not sure what type of broth was used, but it was really disappointing. Nothing could be added to mask the taste of the broth. My sister and I eventually scooped some noodles out of the broth into a separate bowl, and we added some sauce from our sweet/sour shrimp dish, which tasted pretty ok. 

Warning: Their food is pretty spicy, even for the average Korean!
1st time here. Very good, cute little clean hole in the wall. The waitress was very nice and went over what was what and how you eat it.

WoW!  Located in the weirdest strip mall on the west side of town, is this piece of asian food heaven.   There's a Japanese restaurant, Cafe Ga Hyang, tattoo parlor, Siamese Kitchen then what looks like a heavy metal/rock bar..so strange but great at the same time!  Gotta love it!

They have an array of Chinese and Korean dishes which range from $5 for appetizers to $16.95 for one of their Korean dishes.  I had Kalbi dish, and it was delicious!  And I didn't share, because it was so good! 

It's a small restaurant, however, friendly staff and just great food to enjoy with friends and family!

I ordered Dolsot Bibimbap and Samgyupsal. It was tasty, well proportioned and reasonably priced, considering the quantity of food. The atmosphere was cool and the service and service people were very swift and kind. 

I've been to many Korean restaurants in Arizona, California and Korea. This place is pretty good overall and I recommend it. Even if it might be out of your way, I'd still go there and devour food. This place is worth a try even just once. 

Oh, and there's more Banchan than any Korean restaurant I've been to in Arizona. Solid restaurant and I'd go back, even though it takes over half an hour.

One thing I really miss about Southern California is the vast selection of Asian restaurants. It's pretty slim pickings out here in Glendale unfortunately. When I found Cafe Ga Hyang in the Phoenix, I seriously jumped for joy. Stopped in with my family this past weekend and basically had a huge feast. We ordered:

-Ddeokboki appetizer: rice cakes cooked and tossed in a spicy sauce. There is even some veggies and fish cake thrown in. SO GOOD and A MUST ORDER. 
-Jjamppong (or Cham Pong as it's written in the menu): spicy seafood noodle soup. It's pretty large so either order with a group of friends or when you are EXTREMELY hungry. Delicious! My mom was raving about it.
-Dolsat Kalbi Bibimpap: Rice mixed with veggies and beef. Sounds very plain but it seriously delicious. It comes with sauces on the side so you can personalize it a bit. This was my sister's favorite.
-Naengmyun = Cold Noodles. I can't really describe this dish too well. It's buckwheat noodles served in a bowl of ice water, rock sugar and pickled veggies. Sounds funny I know, but it is actually really good. I enjoyed this dish as it was a nice palate cleanser for all the spice I was eating.

For a Korean restaurant, the service was actually pretty good. It seemed like there was only one waitress working the entire restaurant but she checked on us often and was nice. My only quip was that overall the restaurant could have been a bit cleaner as my table was somewhat sticky when I arrived hah, but the delicious food made up for it for the most part. I shall be back!

This is the best Korean food I've had in Arizona and given that we have a decent sized Asian population, stores and restaurants here that's a big compliment! I had the Kalbi Bibimbap and the Jap Chae noodles. This is what I always order in every Korean reastaurant so I have a lot to compare it to. Both were very fresh with excellent flavor. Service was great, very friendly and helpful wait staff. The garnishes were fresh and very tasty as well. Damn I love those little potatoe cubes. If you've never had Korean food they had photos on the wall of the most popular menu items.  My only complaint is that it's a bit expensive but that's not a bad mark against this particular restaurant because I feel like all Korean restaurants are about the same price, $10-$12 for an entree with very little meat.  However, I still loved it and although I wished I had a little more protein it was still a value in that it was well prepared and tasted great!

I've eaten at a Korean restaurant one other time where we got to sit on pillows on the floor.  This was in a different city, in a different state, in a different time, in a different point of my life....My experience at Cafe Ga Hyang was not as good as that time, but I'll give it three stars for the food.

I was anticipating the banchan because I like little bowls of numerous treats on the table, but most of the items were too tangy for my palate.  

Also, I made the mistake of not grabbing my bowl of food right way.  The woman serving our table mixed it "for me" and added sauce while saying, "This is how you eat it."

I kept calm and carried on, but I was seething inside.  I don't like my food mixed with rice - ever!  And how could she possibly know whether or not I wanted any sauce!!  I didn't touch a bite so the other folks at the table ate it up and said it was good.

The other platter which I ordered (something fish-y) was good as were the spring rolls too.  Someone else ordered a salmon plate and that was okay.  If it weren't for the tasty garnish, it would not have impressed me.
Clean, friendly, fast! First time and everything was so good. It's kind of hidden and small but prices are fair.

Met friends here for lunch.  the only thing on the menu which looked familiar was chicken terriyaki.
YUK.  Never again.  They used dark meat which was fatty and grissly.  Those are parts of the chicken I throw away. Not even fit for my cat.
I will stick to Tokyo Express for my chicken terriyaki from now on.

A friend of mine who is keen on looking out for my best interests brought up an interesting idea. 

"Why don't you delete your old reviews and start fresh for the new year and do the same next year"

It does make sense. Is a review from 2009 really relevant in 2012? Probably not. But I do like the idea and will take this into serious consideration and wipe my entire review data base from the cyber world and start fresh. But this is a rather daunting task and it will have to wait till after the weekend.

Fish head stew, an off the menu item here is one of those that I tried towards the end of 2011. I consider myself an adventurous eater, but the thought of fish heads in my belly would require serious amounts of sojou in my system. 

I was not that confident when the Concierge suggested we check out Ga Hyang and we would be amazed and "blown away" by this place. I must admit, there is better Korean in LA, but being this is the desert it really isn't bad. Effort is put into putting together quality dishes, but one piece of advice. You can tone down on the spice and just let the pork belly speak for itself.

A pretty good good Korean Bunshik Jib (Everything Restaurants)
Banchan is 7-8 dishes, food is above average and the atmosphere is pretty spot on~

A caveat is that it is a tad pricey especially when compared to   and other restaurants like this in LA. 

The two ladies that helped me on my visits don't shy away from suggestions and are pretty helpful!
Ultra cool peeps, great service. Nice and quant decor and atmosphere. Nice ma and pa Asian restaurant !

Like another Yelper has mentioned-hey, I'm from California too and Korean food is something I seriously love. Don't get me wrong, I don't mean to say Cafe Ga Hyang isn't authentic but it's just A-OK. Then again my sweet, sassy Ahjummas who run the cafe you are probably the best Korean spot in this town, so... nolja~!

Ate here with my family and noticed the slow service, this seems to be an apparent trend amongst Korean restaurants where the owners are a pair of women running the entire place on their own. We finally got to order after being served waters, banchan and ordered the: Jajangmyeon, Kalbi Dolsot Bibimbap and Bulgogi. The food took a while, but came out in huge portions. 

Banchan- tasted alright, though my favorites were the cucumber kimchi, fishcake and shredded daikon kimchi. Everything else was a bit too sweet or lacked in flavor.

Jajangmyeon- noodles not as chewy, sauce was good with pieces of carrot, potato, onion and beef, garnished with cucumber slices and had a portion enough to feed 3 people. Was told this dish takes long because they make their own noodles, but wish they were a bit more chewy.

Bulgogi- good flavor, but seems to be marinated for too long as the meat's texture started to feel grainy and overly tender. perhaps if there was a more meaty chew to it, it would be good.

The service here does lack, but it is understaffed. Saw a lot of parties leave, after being left to wait for one of the women to take their oder. Food is okay in terms of taste, price on the menu does not reflect actual price on the bill and is a bit expensive. For 3 orders, our bill was about $50 which seems a bit excessive. The only good thing I would say is that they are open late and is one of the few Korean restaurants in the area.

The service was very slow. We had to wait 15 minutes just to get water. And then another 30 for our meal!

Food was pretty good. Bulgogi was on point - very flavorful. If I were to come back, I would have that they would up the ante in terms of speed and staff.

Right off the bat the waitress was very rude. Knowingly that we were Asians, she asked "cash only, ok?" We automatically assumed it was because of the broken credit card machine. Nope, not the case. People paid with credit cards whilst we were eating. That's just straight up bullshit. Another group of Americans came in and not once did she mention cash only. Every business has to pay taxes and it is illegal to avoid it. Now on to the food, we ordered spicy rice cakes for appetizer. It was bomb! I ordered spicy tofu soup with white rice and the soup was very bland. I wouldn't order again. My sisters ordered the bibimbap and they said it was pretty good.

Real Korean food! Finally. I have had a craving all week and just as I am heading to the airport, I checked Yelp on last time and boom! Just around a mile from where I was staying, I find this little gem.  Small nicely decorated dining area but a little hard to find.  Don't let the outside fool you.  The inside is really nice.    

Tucked into the northwest corner strip mall at 43rd and Olive; there appears to be a small collection of little south Asian restaurants.  The store front windows are covered in newspaper or some kind of board in the windows, to defuse the direct assault of the afternoon sun.  I was surprised to find this happy little Korean cafe for lunch stop on my way to the airport.  109 degrees outside, nice dark and cool inside. 

The prices were normal for Korean BBQ and the menu had everything I craved. It was hard not to try the Seafood pancake, spicy rice cakes and an entree. I wanted to make it quick and kept myself from ordering more than one item.  I am sure the others on the plane would not have appreciated the smell from leftover seafood pancake. 

I ordered Duk Mando Guk - Dumpling and rice cake soup.  Huge bowl of tasty rice cakes and dumplings in a light broth with dropped egg, green onion and pieces of carrot. 

This restaurant is not a steakhouse or BBQ grill house - the difference is rice cake.  The Korean restaurant that wants to be considered more upscale will not have rice cake in any dish on their menu.  It is considered street food (like french fires) and not worthy.  

I love rice cakes.  Spicy rice cakes, rice cake soup, hot pots with rice cakes -  Service was good. Not too crowded. The soup was perfect, as well as, the banchan that can with it.  I was in and out in 45 minutes.

Very good selection of side dishes. Sweet and sour pork, teriyaki salmon, and kalbi dolsot bibimbap were spot on. Waiters were attentive and atmosphere very Korean... Just a bit pricey, esp 11.99 for the bibimbap and 13 for the salmon. The sweet and sour was also 13 or so but that plate was huge and could feed two. Unfortunately the sweet and sour dish doesn't come with rice so its another 1.50 for a small bowl. What was unique about the sweet and sour dish was that it also had cooked strawberries in it!

Ok, so this is literally thee best Korean joint I have found in Phoenix. When you walk in it's like you're in Korea! The lady was kind to us & taught us how to eat the food the right way. She even served us, as in put food into our mouth (it wasn't that weird lol) 
If you like authentic, this is the place! 
4 stars because the food was da bomb!!
& because I killed a roach in the bathroom! it was a small baby one, & in the bathroom (who's never seen a roach in a bathroom right?). 


It's our little hole in the wall gem!

Nummy num num

One of the best Korean restaurants in the Valley.  In a somewhat seedy area, but you're in for a treat once you make it past the tattoo parlor and the rough looking guy staring folks down outside.

They serve kimchee sides with meals as you find in real Korean eateries-- all very good.  Kalbi and bulgogi dishes are tasty and flavorful.  Service is very pleasant, as well.  

Cafe GH reminds of the small Korean restaurants in Chicago and LA.  May just want to keep an eye on your car while you eat.

Tip: You can hit Seoul Market across the intersection to stock up after eating.  Good prices on basics.  Best kimchee selection we've found in Phoenix.

I love it here!! When I can't get my mom's home cooked Korean food or if I'm to lazy to cook my own this place is the place to go!!  

 ^.^

We LOVE this place!!  We have been often and have never had anything we didn't like - our favorites are the duk boki, tang soo yuk (fried beef), cham pong (spicy seafood noodle soup), and jja jjang myun (black bean noodle). We've tried a few other items as well and they have actually all been very good. The ambience is laid back and relaxed, and the owner and the waitress here are absolutely a delight. And they're open till 2am some nights! This is one of our favorite stops on this side of town.
The best place in the valley so far to really good Korean. Service is always good, mama gives you hints on what else to do with your leftovers. Great place. all the sides are to die for.

One of the worst Korean food I've ever had. The bean sprout came on bad. We ordered beef noodle soup, but there's hardly any beef in it. The environment was messy. It was way overpriced. Damn rip off.

Best Korean food in town, hands down!

Food is AMAZING. The place is a bit dirty.

I was fortunate enough to read the article in Phoenix Mag that mentioned this wonderful place. I had the BiBim Bap with beef for lunch and the serving was so plentiful I did not have dinner that evening. Everything was great and the home made hot sauce was very flavorful with almost a hit of BBQ/smoky flavor, I would not consider it a "traditional" hot sauce, but it was wonderful! I gave a four star rating since this is the second time I've tried BiBim Bap and DO NOT consider myself an expert on Korean food, but will be back for more in the future. Don't let the unasuming strip mall turn you away, it is worth the visit.

We came to this place from a fair distance in order to satisfy our Korean food cravings. There's signs on the walls saying they've been voted "Best in the Valley" for Korean food, and the aromas seemed promising. But we were very disappointed. 
First, there was one woman who was servicing the entire establishment. This was not so much a problem as there were only two other tables when we initially got there, and there are only a handful of tables there, but as the guests multiplied quickly the service became extremely slow along with it - to the point where my husband had to walk to the front of the restaurant to notify her that we were ready to leave 20 minutes ago and could we kindly have the check?
Next the food. The Korean small plates were all bland, and when I got my Bibimbap bowl, I was equally unimpressed by the flavors. It was apparent the ingredients were fresh, but it was so mediocre that although it came in a large serving size, I didn't even bother to take home leftovers. When I moved my bowl away from me to signify I was done with my meal, my fingers brushed on the bowl and stained my hand black! (See for yourself in my picture!)
Finally - there's no alcohol on the menu!! I put two exclamations points to emphasize this because if you still choose to try this place out, you are going to need a few drinks in you to tolerate the service and bland food. I recommend the sushi place or bar next door to get your fix to forget your troubles.
Don't miss the Hameul Pa Jeon (seafood & veggie pancake) no matter what you do! Awesome banchan. Great food. Do the duk boki too!

The atmosphere feels like a restaurant along the streets of Korea (not your cleanest of places, but very cozy) with authentic Korean service (for better or worse), meaning the tones can come off rather rude if you are unprepared, but they mean well. For example, my friend had preferred a non-spiced soondubu (soft tofu soup), so she ordered the white soondubu (no pun intended... or maybe just a little pun intended lol). The lady made a face of disgust and said "Ugh no spicy??? Spicy is much better!" My friend was a bit surprised/upset by the judgmental tone, but you just have to understand certain interactions among Asians and not take it personally.

Cons:  They are rather stingy with banchan, limiting refills to only 2 side dishes... even justifying by saying you are supposed to eat your main entree.  They also recently switched to cash-only (seemingly only for the Asian customers, though I cannot confirm this).

Pros:  Despite the cons, this is truly the best Korean food in Phoenix and comparable to that of K'Town in LA or Korea.  We've tried many of their dishes and some of my favorites are Haemul Pa Jeon (Seafood Pancake), Bibim Naengmyeon (Cold Noodles), Kalbi Tang (Beef Short Rib Soup), and Soondae Jjigae (Blood Sausage Soup).

From our most recent visit:
Haemul Pa Jeon (Seafood Pancake):  Tip: Extra crispy - the intensified aroma teases you from the moment the dish is served... and the satisfying crunch from each bite layers your tastebuds.

Bibim Naengmyeon (Korean Cold Noodles): I crave the naengmyeon I had from Seoul... to this day.  This isn't that, but settles my cravings more than any other naengmyeon in Phoenix. 

Summary:
Service: 2-3 Stars
Food: Definitely worth it

It is not your Vegas buffet, but you can find a tour of Asia in this west side strip mall sampling cuisine from Japan, Thai, Chinese, and Korean.  We had a party of 13 which took up 1/2 of the restaurant.  I had ordered the cha jang myun (black bean sauce with noodles) and sweet and sour pork.  It is not the typical Chinese version of sweet and sour pork.   The rest of party had ordered Kalbi, sul lung tang (a hearty, luxuriant beef broth made from ox bones), and champong (hot spicy noodle).    The dishes were huge.  I think I over ate, but it was just so good.  Our server was great and she thought of everything before we thought of requesting extra plates for our birthday cake.    They were very accommodating for a large group.  It's a great place I will definitely go back.

Fantastic! How often can we say in Arizona that we have a Korean restaurant open until 2am?!? Not only is that great, but to top it off, the food was excellent. My girlfriend had the squid stir fry which they cut the squid the cross pattern which allowed it to stay soft, and I had the kimchi soup, which was fantastic as well. 

It's a bit far from where I live, but I would love to give it another try when I'm near this area of town!

Best authentic Korean Food in Arizona- We tried them all and this place is hands down GOOD! from the bachan to the soups.. the spicy pork is so good! when we need our Korean fix, this is the place. Order the korean seafood pancake, spicy pork, and their soups

Okayish price but food doesn't live up to the hype. Also the portion is not really on the generous side. Beef soup literally had two thin slices of beef and galbi bibimbob had very small amount of meat. But that's not why I'm leaving a one star review. The owner is rude as hell. She literally scolded us for not eating "correctly" and just wouldn't stop talking. She put extra salt in my soup and attempted to "correct" other people's dishes as well (e.g. mixing the food). Would not recommend for people who doesn't like their food being touched.

I love Café Ga Hyang. 

I'll admit I'm not extremely well versed in Korean cuisine. I'm just a bit beyond the pointing at the menu "I'll have that" stage. I do, however, have a Korean food advocate in the family. After spending a time in NYC with two Korean roommates, this family member returned to Arizona with a taste for Korean soap operas and Korean food. She was greatly relieved to find Café Ga Hyang and considers it one of two favorite local Korean spots. I, however, can recognize an outstanding family run restaurant, regardless of ethnicity, when I see one. The location in an aging strip center does not leave a strong initial impression. Do not be deterred. The Korean television, the décor, the private booths, the big long tables, the late hours (open daily until 2:00 a.m.)... and of course the food, will leave a positive lasting impression by the time you depart.. 

The entire restaurant is served by one waitress, which I'm sure slows things down at peak times, but seems to be a way to keep the family in charge of interacting with diners. A great idea if that's the thought process. Our server showed visible concern when we ate very little of one of the dishes we ordered, a genuine reaction you seldom see while dining. No problem with the food. We just ordered too much and expended too much effort on the glorious array of small side dishes. She then packed it up for us to go. We dined in one of the enclosed booths. Fun and very private. We felt like we had the restaurant to ourselves. Simply great service. We also appreciated when a little instruction was volunteered, without the slightest hint of condescension, regarding how to best eat (and enjoy) one of the dishes.

I will definitely volunteer to return whenever the family needs another fix of Korean cuisine.

my wife was not feeling well so we ordered to take out. They were so accomodating and friendly and willing to help me order.
The food was memorable and I go back often. Priced right, not flashy...give this one a try

Whaaaaaa? They close at two am. Oh em geee. Not like I was craving Korean food  at 12 am or anything. Haha.

I always get the bibimbap no meat., The only thing I can have really, but it is so good. I'm not really a big fan of the stone cooker bowl that came with.. my rice was burnt.  Other than that, but my meal was delicious.

The ambiance is chill and quiet... (til I walk in)  im so loud. Haha

I've been to this Korean restaurant a few times with my girlfriend.  This is her favorite Korean restaurant to go to.  We always split the xiao xiao mein, while I believe this is considered to be a Chinese dish it is one of the few places we can get it, and in most cases it is quite delicious.  Her go to dish is the seafood  dolsot bibimbap which she absolutely loves, and any other Korean restaurant that we go to either doesn't have it or it just isn't nearly as good.  I generally order the bulgogi which I would say is is pretty good.  The restaurant appears to be family run which I really like, and the people there are always really nice.  The only reason I give it 4 stars instead of 5 is there are some consistency issues where a couple of times the food just wasn't as good.

Finding your favorite cuisine is great. Finding your favorite dish is monumental. Finding your favorite version of your favorite dish is monument-al, shrine-al, temple-al, nativity scene-al. 

Factor in that it's one a.m. and I'm basically just weeping on the floor of this little Korean joint in a strip mall. 

Why? Because Kalbi dol sot bibim bap. So damn crispy. So flavorful. So fresh, 'n' so clean. So egg. The greatest wall of crispy rice action I've ever known... I'm a one-dolsot woman now.

I have tried Korean food in many places in the PHX Metro and I have to say this is one of my absolute favorites.  They offer a wonderful selection of Banchan (side dishes typical of Korean dining.) usually serving up to 8 cheop (dishes) along with steamed rice and the table's entre(s).  Their BBQ items are priced in line with other Korean restaurants in town (a little pricy but average) but the bottomless banchan makes up for it. 
My go to dish here is the Kimchi Stew, especially on a cloudy cool day or after a overindulged night on the town.  I have also made a great lunch out of just the banchan and rice.  

The service has always been excellent and polite.  Finding it may be a little tricky as it is in a strip mall between 43rd and 44th Ave Next to a large AYCE Sushi place and tucked between a Dry Cleaners and a Tattoo Parlor. 

I have found myself willing to drive all the way up here from Downtown PHX just to get my fix, it is THAT good.

The food is delicious, but the service is slow and way understaffed. We had to wait for almost an hour to get our food because it looked like it was the only one lady in the whole restaurant managing the kitchen and tables. There was some minor communication issues, but for the most part she was friendly. The food is inexpensive here. We spent about $24 for two people and I had leftovers to take home. It was very filling, just wish the service was better. I'll definitely do takeout though.

Very good Korean food, especially for being in the middle of Arizona! There is something for everyone here, even those who are not familiar with Korean/Asian cuisine. 

We ordered the Dak-Galbi (chicken barbeque), Salmon Entree (lightly grilled), and the Spicy Octopus Stir Fry. All were delicious. The ban-chan (traditional side dishes) were all authentic and tasty - try them all even if they look different than what you usually eat!

My coworker and I went for lunch yesterday  and we thought the food wasn't bad. I ended up having the runs all morning and throwing up. My coworker called me and told me he also had the runs. Seem's to me like we got food poisoning. Will not be going back ever.

This is one of my go to Korean Restaurants in Glendale. Serves traditional dishes prepared and presented traditionally. On this particular visit the credit card service was down and only accepted cash. Just in case your visiting soon. 
The feel is always very traditional and the decor adds to the feel of the times I ate in Seoul. 
Today I had the Hot Bipimpap. One on my favorite Korean dishes. As always it was delicious and served just like I was in South Korea. The only thing I must point out and I'm just really getting nit picky is the beef did not have the soft fresh taste as this restaurant always has in the past. Aside from that I am pleased with the taste of my meal and the endless sides of Kimshi, and all the other sides traditionally served.
The prices are comparable to any other Korean place around the valley. Fair prices without going overboard. 
One thing I really appreciate is it's always clean. Never been here and it's dirty. Even when it's busy. 
Oh and the water tasted good.  No tap horrible flavor making me want to buy a bottled water.

I've been here twice now.  BOTH times the service was horrible.  The lady is not very attentive and will get to your table in a not-so-very hurried pace.  On my second trip I had to physically get up from my seat and walk over to let her know we needed service.  The food was decent but the side dishes were horrible.  I almost want to say they were "old," which I know is hard to say because most dishes are spoiled/old but this quality was just so poor that it left a very unpleasant taste in my mouth.  

Side dishes are a critical subset to the entree during any Korean meal.  It is imperative that the side dishes are made from the most fresh ingredients and this did not taste that way.

COST:  3/5
The foods were a bit pricey and as I mentioned above, with the quality of the food I think the price is not worth it.  It would've been different if it was a singular incident but on both my visits this was a common issue.

SERVICE:  1/5
Again, horrible service during both my two visits.  The staff is usually very limited if it's not JUST the lady but even still they are not attentive and not generally carry the situational awareness you would expect from restaurant servers.

FOOD:  3/5
The food was decent.  I ordered the black noodles (Jja Jang Myun).  Quantity is plentiful and the black sauce is very flavorful.  It's not exactly what you might be used to from Korea but it comes close.  I also ordered Dwenjang JJigae (bean curd soup) which was very good but then again, if you are Korean you BETTER know how to make this.

DECOR/AMBIANCE: 4/5
Decent spot on the inside.  The place seems very clean and well-kept.  Seating is plentiful with private booths along one side and large tables for larger groups on the other.

Everyone had raved about this place and it was on a long list of joints to check out. I'm now extremely angry I didn't try it sooner. It took a while to warm up to the ambiance, but as soon as Sun came out with our food it was like we were welcomed guests in her home. She showed us the best flavor combinations and even dished out plates for us to share. And the food... the flavors were varied and rich, and the dishes marked spicy actually had serious heat. My sister-in-law, who used to live in Korea, even commented at how much the food brought back great memories.

Speaking of the food, the Haemul Pajeon was a hit with all of us; it's huge, with the perfect crisp on the outside and hearty chunks of seafood in a tender pancake/omelette (whatever you want to call it). With a touch of sauce it is delightful. You can tell there is so much care taken in the preparation of these dishes, even the green tea ice cream mochi was served sliced, with a beautiful drizzle of subtle sauce (aloe, maybe?) and whipped cream. I'm totally sold on another strip mall treasure.
It's different but the sweet and sour pork was really good. Love that it's open late and I mean late 1am.

The BF and I went here tonight with the International Supper Club and it was really good! I have only had Korean food a few times before and this was by far the best I've had (the other places were in Seattle, so that's pretty good). The lady who worked there was helpful, a little stressed out, but helpful. She managed to get everyone's food out at around the same time and it was all steaming hot...literally steaming. I had the spicy soup with sliced beef and it was really good. I thought it could be a little spicier, but it had a lot of flavor and the beef fell apart. The BF had the bulgogi and it was amazing! Very soft and flavorful. The sides were all interesting...we got 4 sets of 7-8 side dishes to share. The tofu side was the best, and I don't particularly like tofu, but this was firm, spicy, and delicious. The bok choy, spicy potato, cucumbery thing, and kim chi were all very good. Now, this place is not particularly cheap, but we had so much food, it was crazy! Plus, it all tasted good. I would definitely come back here in the future!

My party of 7, including 3 kids, came here for a late night dinner.  From the outside, we couldn't see through the windows and we thought maybe it was a bar and stayed by our car, but after letting the men go inside, they came back out to get us.  Being from Hawaii, I felt pretty much at home here because there was a flat screen TV showing Korean dramas and it made me think of my mom back home who watches them all the time.  One thing that my party wanted was meat jun/chun, but there wasn't any one the menu.  We ordered galbi and a soup to share with the table that had octopus and beef.  After we put in our order, it took a while for us to get any food and I didn't even expect the banchan side dishes to come out before our entrees came out.  The galbi tasted good and it came with the huge bones that my husband likes to gnaw on.  The soup was spicy but chock full of octopus, clams, mussels, shrimp, and beef.  It had to cook on the propane portable stove for a few minutes to cook the raw octopus and beef that was visible on top of the soup.  I didn't have room for dessert, but everyone else wanted to eat their mochi ice cream but the lone lady serving us said there was no mochi so everyone opted to eat the red bean ice cream.  This place was a lifesaver for us Hawaii people visiting Phoenix as we were dying to eat rice and at a place that was open late.
One of the few really good Korean food in the valley.  Service is amazing.  Best seafood pancake I've ever had.  This is truly a hidden gem.

I've had Korean food in lots of cities in the US, this place still blows my mind with the flavor! Nothing like a little old Korean lady who likes to show you how she ate when she grew up in Korea. She's even fed me when I didn't know how to use some of the sauces. Aside from her being friendly, you can taste the love and hard work they put in their food. The Banchan is never the same here due to Sun, making whatever she's growing in her garden at the current season. This is one of the many reasons why I love the owner of this place. Some of my favorites are, baby fern stems, sesame leaves, and her Napa kimchi. The Duk bokki here is to die for.
